title: What Maritime Pilots Need to Know about COVID-19
source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, National Center for Health Statistics
annotation: This web page provides information and answers to questions about COVID-19 and maritime pilots:  As a maritime pilot, how can I protect myself and slow the spread of COVID-19?; What steps should pilots’ associations take?; and Where can I get more information?
access_notes: Link to page in Chinese: https://chinese.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/maritime-pilots.htmlLink to page in Korean: https://korean.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/maritime-pilots.htmlLink to page in Spanish: https://espanol.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/maritime-pilots.htmlLink to page in Vietnamese: https://vietnamese.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/maritime-pilots.html

title: Coronavirus Disease (COVID-19): Considerations for Retirement Communities and Independent Living Facilities
source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Office of Infectious Diseases
annotation: This web page, updated on October 30, 2020, offers considerations for ways in which administrators of retirement communities and independent living facilities can help protect residents, workers, visitors, and communities, and slow the spread of COVID-19.
access_notes: Link to page in Chinese: https://chinese.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/retirement/considerations.htmlLink to page in Korean: https://korean.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/retirement/considerations.htmlLink to page in Spanish: https://espanol.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/retirement/considerations.htmlLink to page in Vietnamese: https://vietnamese.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/retirement/considerations.html

title: COVID-19 Infection Fatality Ratio Estimates from Seroprevalence
annotation: This 18-page report discusses infection fatality ratio (IFR), a key statistic for estimating the burden of COVID-19 that has been continuously debated throughout the current pandemic. Previous estimates have relied on data early in the epidemic, or have not fully accounted for uncertainty in serological test characteristics and delays from onset of infection to seroconversion, death, and antibody waning. After screening 175 studies, this study identified 10 representative antibody surveys to obtain updated estimates of the infection fatality rate using a modeling framework that addresses the limitations.
authors: Brazeau, Nicholas; Verity, Robert; Jenks, Sara; Fu, Han; Whittaker, Charles
access_notes: Direct link to document: https://www.imperial.ac.uk/media/imperial-college/medicine/mrc-gida/2020-10-29-COVID19-Report-34.pdfLink to Supplementary data: https://www.imperial.ac.uk/media/imperial-college/medicine/mrc-gida/2020-10-29-COVID19-Report-34-supplement.pdfLink to Supplement excluded studies: https://www.imperial.ac.uk/media/imperial-college/medicine/mrc-gida/2020-10-29-COVID19-Report-34-Supplement-excluded-studies.xlsx

title: Operating Schools During COVID-19: CDC's Considerations
source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Center for Preparedness and Response
annotation: The CDC offers these considerations, updated on October 29, 2020, for ways in which schools can help protect students, teachers, administrators, and staff and slow the spread of COVID-19. Schools can determine, in collaboration with state and local health officials to the extent possible, whether and how to implement these considerations while adjusting to meet the unique needs and circumstances of the local community.
access_notes: Link to page in Chinese: https://chinese.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/schools-childcare/schools.htmlLink to page in Korean: https://korean.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/schools-childcare/schools.htmlLink to page in Spanish: https://espanol.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/schools-childcare/schools.htmlLink to page in Vietnamese: https://vietnamese.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/schools-childcare/schools.html

title: Ohio Pandemic Influenza Public Engagement Demonstration Project
source: Center for Public Health Practice [Ohio State University, College of Public Health]
annotation: This is a report on a project to help state and local level decision-makers manage response and recovery plans concerning mass fatalities as a result of an outbreak of pandemic influenza in Ohio and is product of a series of meetings with stakeholders and representatives of the public.

title: Coronavirus Disease (COVID-19) Considerations for Institutions of Higher Education
source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Office of Infectious Diseases
annotation: This web page, updated on October 29, 2020, provides updates on expanded considerations on care for students and staff when becoming ill in an institution of higher learning setting, considerations on ventilation, considerations on food service, and considerations for contact tracing.
access_notes: Link to page in Chinese: https://chinese.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/colleges-universities/considerations.htmlLink to page in Korean: https://korean.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/colleges-universities/considerations.htmlLink to page in Spanish: https://espanol.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/colleges-universities/considerations.htmlLink to page in Vietnamese: https://vietnamese.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/colleges-universities/considerations.html

title: Coronavirus Disease (COVID-19) Staffing Resources: Staffing Resources and Guidance
source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Office of Infectious Diseases
annotation: This web page, updated on October 29, 2020, provides resources for state, tribal, local, and territorial health departments on staffing the public health workforce to coordinate the response to the COVID-19 pandemic and reopening state, tribal, local, and territorial programs. Charts show CDC field team deployments and quarantine station deployments by date, and resources from other organizations are provided.

title: Coronavirus Disease (COVID-19) FAQs for Wildland Firefighters
source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Office of Infectious Diseases
annotation: This web page, updated on October 29, 2020, provides answers to frequently asked questions about wildland firefighters and COVID-19. Topics include how to prevent infection and spread, prioritization of testing, and precautions wildland firefighters should take.
access_notes: Link to page in Chinese: https://chinese.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/wildland-firefighters-faq.htmlLink to page in Korean: https://korean.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/wildland-firefighters-faq.htmlLink to page in Spanish: https://espanol.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/wildland-firefighters-faq.htmlLink to page in Vietnamese: https://vietnamese.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/wildland-firefighters-faq.html

title: Cultural Competency Program for Disaster Preparedness and Crisis Response
source: Office of Minority Health [U.S. Department of Health and Human Services]
annotation: This course provides the knowledge, skills, and awareness to best serve all individuals, regardless of cultural or linguistic background, during every phase of a disaster. It is for EMT/First Responders, Emergency Managers, Psychologists and Psychiatrists, Social Workers, Dentists, and any disaster or emergency response personnel interested in learning more about culturally and linguistically appropriate services.

title: Implementation of Mitigation Strategies for Communities with Local COVID-19 Transmission
source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Office of Infectious Diseases
annotation: This web page, updated on October 29, 2020, describes the goals, guiding principles, and strategies for community mitigation to reduce or prevent local COVID-19 transmission. Community mitigation activities are actions that people and communities can take to slow the spread of a new virus with pandemic potential.
access_notes: This page is available in Chinese, Korean, Spanish, and Vietnamese. Link to Mitigation Strategies for Santa Clara, CA: https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/downloads/Santa-Clara_Community_Mitigation.pdfLink to Mitigation Strategies for Seattle, WA: https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/downloads/Seattle_Community_Mitigation.pdfLink to Mitigation Strategies for New Rochelle, NY: https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/downloads/New-Rochelle_Community_Mitigation.pdf Link to Mitigation Strategies for Florida: https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/downloads/FL_Community_Mitigation.pdfLink to Mitigation Strategies for Massachusetts: https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/downloads/MA_Community_Mitigation.pdf

title: Considerations for Communities of Faith
source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Office of Infectious Diseases
annotation: This interim guidance, updated on October 29, 2020, offers the general considerations to help communities of faith discern how best to practice their beliefs while keeping their staff and congregations safe during the COVID-19 pandemic.
access_notes: Link to page in Chinese: https://chinese.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/faith-based.htmlLink to page in Korean: https://korean.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/faith-based.htmlLink to page in Spanish: https://espanol.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/faith-based.htmlLink to page in Vietnamese: https://vietnamese.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/faith-based.html

title: Polling Locations and Voters: Interim Guidance to Prevent Spread of Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19)
source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Office of Infectious Diseases
annotation: This guidance, updated on October 29, 2020, provides expanded guidance on changes to operations, procedures, and facilities for polling locations; added reminders to maintain accessibility; and added recommendations for voters.
access_notes: Link to Toolkit for Reducing the Spread of COVID-19 During Elections: https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/election-polling-locations/elections-toolkit.htmlLink to guidance in Chinese: https://chinese.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/election-polling-locations.htmlLink to guidance in Korean: https://korean.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/election-polling-locations.htmlLink to guidance in Spanish: https://espanol.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/election-polling-locations.htmlLink to guidance in Vietnamese: https://vietnamese.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/election-polling-locations.html

title: Ransomware Activity Targeting the Healthcare and Public Health Sector
annotation: This joint cybersecurity advisory was coauthored by the Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA), the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI), and the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS). It describes the tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs) used by cybercriminals against targets in the Healthcare and Public Health Sector (HPH) to infect systems with Ryuk ransomware for financial gain.
access_notes: Link to advisory in a PDF file: https://us-cert.cisa.gov/sites/default/files/publications/AA20-302A_Ransomware%20_Activity_Targeting_the_Healthcare_and_Public_Health_Sector.pdf

title: Innovating on Campus: Supporting Mental Health of Students of Color During COVID-19 and Beyond
source: Harvard University, Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health
annotation: This one-hour, two-minute presentation discusses what higher education leaders, staff, and faculty should do to help young people of color successfully navigate today’s campus climate, social distancing protocols, and remote learning experiences.
authors: Martin, Phillip; Krislov, Marvin; Kumar, Meeta; Chavous, Tabbye; Kim, Josephine

title: Common Investigation Protocol for Investigating Suspected SARS-CoV-2 Reinfection
source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Office of Infectious Diseases
annotation: This protocol is designed to support a common public health investigation into suspected SARS-CoV-2 reinfection cases across jurisdictions. Confirming SARS-CoV-2 reinfection requires advanced laboratory diagnostic support built upon advanced planning to implement this protocol, or a locally adapted version, with referral of specimens to supporting laboratory networks.
access_notes: Link to Investigative Criteria for Suspected Cases of SARS-CoV-2 Reinfection (ICR): https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/php/invest-criteria.html

title: SARS-CoV-2 Viral Culturing at CDC
source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Office of Infectious Diseases
annotation: This web page for laboratories provides information about how the CDC is using SARS-CoV-2 in various ways, including: To test serum collected from people who have recovered from COVID-19 to look for antibody that might block viral infections; and to determine when people shed live virus during the disease. This information has shaped CDC’s guidance on when to discontinue transmission-based precautions for patients.

title: Interim Clinical Guidance for Management of Patients with Confirmed Coronavirus Disease (COVID-19)
source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Office of Infectious Diseases
annotation: This interim guidance, updated on October 27, 2020, is for clinicians caring for patients with confirmed infection with severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2), the virus that causes coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19).

title: Fact Sheet for Healthcare Providers: MassARRAY SARS-CoV-2 Panel
annotation: This three-page fact sheet informs healthcare providers of the significant known and potential risks and benefits of the emergency use of the MassARRAY SARS-CoV-2 Panel. The MassARRAY SARS-CoV-2 Panel is  authorized for use with respiratory specimens collected from individuals suspected of COVID-19 by their healthcare provider.
access_notes: Link to Fact Sheet for Patients: https://www.fda.gov/media/143333/downloadLink to Letter of Authorization: https://www.fda.gov/media/143331/downloadLink to Instructions for Use: https://www.fda.gov/media/143334/download

title: Key Aspects Regarding the Introduction and Prioritisation of COVID-19 Vaccination in the EU/EEA and the UK
source: European Union, European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control
annotation: This 12-page document provides an overview of the key aspects related to the initial phases following the introduction of one or more COVID-19 vaccines in the European Union and European Economic Area (EU/EEA) and the United Kingdom (UK). These components are those usually adopted when a new vaccine is available on the market and integrated into national vaccination schedules.
access_notes: Direct link to document: https://www.ecdc.europa.eu/sites/default/files/documents/Key-aspects-regarding-introduction-and-prioritisation-of-COVID-19-vaccination.pdf

title: Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19) Community Mitigation (Non-U.S. Settings)
source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Office of Infectious Diseases
annotation: This web page, updated on October 26, 2020, provides guidance, documents, posters, and videos about community mitigation measures for COVID-19.
access_notes: Some materials are available in several languages.

title: Strategies for Optimizing the Supply of Disposable Medical Gloves
source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Office of Infectious Diseases
annotation: This web page offers a series of strategies or options to optimize supplies of disposable medical gloves in healthcare settings when there is limited supply. These considerations are intended for use by federal, state, and local public health officials; leaders in occupational health services and infection prevention and control programs; and other leaders in healthcare settings who are responsible for developing and implementing policies and procedures for preventing pathogen transmission in healthcare settings.

title: Flowchart for Management of HCWs (Health Care Workers) with Exposure to a Person with COVID-19
source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Office of Infectious Diseases
annotation: This web page, updated on October 25, 2020, provides a flowchart for management of health care workers with exposure in the last 14 days to a person with COVID-19, for both high- and low-risk exposure.

title: CDC’s Diagnostic Multiplex Assay for Flu and COVID-19 at Public Health Laboratories and Supplies
source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Office of Infectious Diseases
annotation: This web page, updated on October 25, 2020, provides information about the CDC Influenza SARS-CoV-2 (Flu SC2) Multiplex Assay, which is a real-time reverse-transcriptase polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) test that detects and differentiates RNA from SARS-CoV-2, influenza A virus, and influenza B virus in upper or lower respiratory specimens. The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) granted an Emergency Use Authorization (EUA) for this test on July 2, 2020.
access_notes: Link to Research Use Only CDC Influenza SARS-CoV-2 (Flu SC2) Multiplex Assay Real-Time RT-PCR Primers and Probes: https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/lab/multiplex-primer-probes.html

title: How to Report COVID-19 Laboratory Data
source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Office of Infectious Diseases
annotation: This web page, updated on October 25, 2020, outlines reporting requirements for laboratories for collecting and sending COVID-19/SARS-CoV-2 laboratory testing data. It also details how to report using standard terminology.

title: Guidance Related to Childcare During COVID-19
annotation: The aim of the strategies provided within this guidance is to reduce risk of COVID-19 exposure and spread of infection to staff, children, and families involved with early care and education programs. The guidance also explores primary prevention such as immunizations, well child care, and special considerations for children with special health care needs.

title: Interim Guidance on Supporting the Emotional and Behavioral Health Needs of Children, Adolescents, and Families During the COVID-19 Pandemic
annotation: This web page details how the COVID-19 pandemic has underscored the need to continue to integrate emotional and behavioral health as part of standard care, and how pediatricians, professionals, families, and agencies can partner together to support the emotional and behavioral health of the nation’s children, adolescents, and families during this public health crisis.

title: Fact Sheet for Healthcare Providers: Sampinute™ COVID-19 Antigen MIA
annotation: This three-page fact sheet informs healthcare providers of the significant known and potential risks and benefits of the emergency use of the Sampinute™ COVID-19 Antigen Magnetic Immunoassay (MIA). The Sampinute™ COVID-19 Antigen MIA is authorized for use using nasopharyngeal swab specimens collected from individuals who are suspected of COVID-19 by their healthcare provider within the first five days of the onset of symptoms.
access_notes: Link to Fact Sheet for Patients: https://www.fda.gov/media/143269/downloadLink to Letter of Authorization: https://www.fda.gov/media/143267/downloadLink to Instructions for Use: https://www.fda.gov/media/143270/download

title: National Wastewater Surveillance System (NWSS): A New Public Health Tool to Understand COVID-19 Spread in a Community
source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Office of Infectious Diseases
annotation: This web page provides information about the National Wastewater Surveillance System (NWSS), initiated in response to the COVID-19 pandemic. The data generated by NWSS will help public health officials to better understand the extent of COVID-19 infections in communities.
access_notes: Link to Developing a Wastewater Surveillance Sampling Strategy: https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/cases-updates/wastewater-surveillance/developing-a-wastewater-surveillance-sampling-strategy.htmlLink to Wastewater Surveillance Testing Methods: https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/cases-updates/wastewater-surveillance/testing-methods.htmlLink to Wastewater Surveillance Data Reporting and Analytics: https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/cases-updates/wastewater-surveillance/data-reporting-analytics.htmlLink to Targeted Wastewater Surveillance at Facilities, Institutions, and Workplaces: https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/cases-updates/wastewater-surveillance/wastewater-workplaces.htmlLink to Public Health Interpretation and Use of Wastewater Surveillance Data: https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/cases-updates/wastewater-surveillance/public-health-interpretation.html

title: Increased Transmission of COVID-19 in the EU/EEA and the UK: Thirteenth Update
source: European Union, European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control
annotation: This 14-page update assesses the risk for the general population and vulnerable individuals in relation to the increase in COVID-19 notification rates in the European Union/European Economic Area (EU/EEA) and the United Kingdom (UK). There has been a considerable further increase in COVID-19 infections, and the current situation represents a major threat to public health.
access_notes: Direct link to document: https://www.ecdc.europa.eu/sites/default/files/documents/RRA-COVID-19-EU-EEA-UK-thirteenth-update-23-Oct-2020.pdf

title: Guide to Global Digital Tools for COVID-19 Response
source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Office of Infectious Diseases
annotation: This guide, updated on October 23, 2020, compares the District Health Information Software (DHIS2), the Surveillance, Outbreak Response Management and Analysis System (SORMAS), Go.Data, Open Data Kit (ODK), Epi Info, CommCare, KoboToolbox, Excel, and paper.  Each has been deployed in various countries for contact tracing, investigations, and/or, in the case of DHIS2 and SORMAS, national surveillance.

title: How to Mitigate COVID-19 Transmission in Densely Populated Areas Globally
source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Office of Infectious Diseases
annotation: This web page, updated on October 23, 2020, provides suggestions for community mitigation measures in densely populated, international, low-resource settings, and describes implementation considerations associated with each measure. Community mitigation activities are actions that people and communities can take to prevent or reduce local COVID-19 transmission.

title: Considerations for Use of SARS-CoV-2 Antigen Testing in Nursing Homes
source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Office of Infectious Diseases
annotation: This web page, updated on October 23, 2020, provides a summary of considerations for use of SARS-CoV-2 (the virus that causes COVID-19) antigen testing in nursing homes and is intended for nursing home providers and state and local public health departments.
access_notes: Link to testing algorithm: https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/downloads/hcp/nursing-home-testing-algorithm-508.pdf

title: Operational Considerations for Adapting a Contact Tracing Program to Respond to the COVID-19 Pandemic
source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Office of Infectious Diseases
annotation: This web page, updated on October 23, 2020, outlines considerations for modifying contact tracing protocols during the COVID-19 pandemic to maximize efficient use of limited resources. It is for CDC country offices, ministries of health, sub-national public health authorities, and other implementing partners in non-U.S. settings.

title: Evaluation and Management Considerations for Neonates At Risk for COVID-19
source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Office of Infectious Diseases
annotation: This guidance, updated on October 23, 2020, is intended to inform healthcare providers about the diagnosis, evaluation, infection prevention and control practices, and disposition of neonates (≤28 days old) with confirmed or suspected COVID-19 or known COVID-19 exposure, including birth to a mother with confirmed or suspected COVID-19.

title: Assessment Tool for Laboratories Implementing SARS-CoV-2 Testing
annotation: This tool, updated on October 23, 2020, has been designed to assess the capacity of laboratories that have implemented or intend to implement testing for SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes novel coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19). The tool is a shortened version of the 2012 laboratory assessment tool that is widely used to assess national laboratory systems and the capacity of laboratories.
access_notes: Direct link to user guide: https://apps.who.int/iris/rest/bitstreams/1310603/retrieveDirect link to tool: https://apps.who.int/iris/rest/bitstreams/1310611/retrieve

title: COVID-19 Case Investigation and Contact Tracing among Refugee, Immigrant, and Migrant (RIM) Populations: Important Considerations for Health Departments
source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Office of Infectious Diseases
annotation: This web page discusses why refugee, immigrant, and migrant populations are at increased risk for COVID-19, and provides guidance, including how health departments can conduct effective case investigation and contact tracing among refugee, immigrant, and migrant populations, and how to overcome language barriers.

title: Learning to Live in a World with the H1N1 Pandemic
source: Center for Strategic and International Studies
annotation: Dr. Harvey Fineberg, president of the Institute of Medicine and Dr. Anthony Fauci, director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases talk about the H1N1 flu outbreak and policy decisions to combat and mitigate the outbreak.
authors: Fauci, Anthony S.

title: Leveraging Existing Resources to Meet the Challenges Faced by People Who Use Drugs or Who Have Substance Use Disorders During the COVID-19 Pandemic
source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Office of Infectious Diseases
annotation: The COVID-19 pandemic has presented challenges in healthcare for those who may be at greater risk for adverse health outcomes such as people who use drugs or people who have a substance use disorder. To better facilitate provision of care, the CDC organized this one-hour Clinician Outreach and Communication Activities (COCA) call to highlight existing resources and exceptions for clinicians who prescribe medications for opioid use disorder, increase awareness of existing community-based linkage to care resources, and discuss the outpatient telemedicine experience from a front-line provider perspective.
authors: Gandotra, Neerj; Rooks-Peck, Cherie; Ryan, Shawn
access_notes: Link to presentation slides: https://emergency.cdc.gov/coca/ppt/2020/PWUD-COCA_10.22.2020_FINAL.pdf

title: Case Investigation and Contact Tracing in Non-Healthcare Workplaces: Information for Employers
source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Office of Infectious Diseases
annotation: This web page, updated on October 22, 2020, provides tips and considerations for how employers can partner with state, tribal, local, or territorial (STLT) health departments and work with their employees on COVID-19 case investigation and contact tracing, which may lower the need for business closures to prevent the spread of the disease.
access_notes: Link to page in Chinese: https://chinese.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/contact-tracing-nonhealthcare-workplaces.htmlLink to page in Korean: https://korean.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/contact-tracing-nonhealthcare-workplaces.htmlLink to page in Spanish: https://espanol.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/contact-tracing-nonhealthcare-workplaces.htmlLink to page in Vietnamese: https://vietnamese.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/contact-tracing-nonhealthcare-workplaces.html

title: Letter of Authorization: Emergency Use Authorization (EUA) of Remdesivir (GS-5734™)
annotation: The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) updated this Emergency Use Authorization (EUA) on October 1, 2020, to permit the emergency use of the unapproved product remdesivir for treatment of suspected or laboratory confirmed coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) in adults and children hospitalized with severe disease. The FDA approved remdesivir for the treatment of COVID-19 requiring hospitalization on October 22, 2020.
access_notes: Link to updated information (October 22, 2020): https://www.fda.gov/news-events/press-announcements/fda-approves-first-treatment-covid-19Link to Fact Sheet for Healthcare Providers: https://www.fda.gov/media/137566/downloadLink to Fact Sheet for Patients and Parents/Caregivers: https://www.fda.gov/media/137565/downloadLink to Frequently Asked Questions on the Emergency Use Authorization for Remdesivir for Certain Hospitalized COVID-19 Patients: https://www.fda.gov/media/137574/downloadLink to FDA Broadens Emergency Use Authorization for Veklury (remdesivir) to Include All Hospitalized Patients for Treatment of COVID-19 (August 28, 2020): https://www.fda.gov/news-events/press-announcements/covid-19-update-fda-broadens-emergency-use-authorization-veklury-remdesivir-include-all-hospitalized

title: Influenza Vaccine Use by Adults in the U.S.
annotation: This report contains data on influenza vaccine use by adults 65 or older, those with high-risk health conditions, health care workers, or those with close contact with high-risk individuals.
authors: Lurie, Nicole

title: Considerations in the Investigation of Cases and Clusters of COVID-19
annotation: This five-page document, updated on October 22, 2020, offers operational guidance to Member States for the rapid investigation of suspected COVID-19 cases after an alert or signal. It is to be used by local, regional, or national health authorities as considerations for investigating cases of COVID-19. A table serves as operational guidance for time-sensitive (within first few days of notification) priority actions after the signal of a COVID-19 case/cluster.
access_notes: Direct link to document: https://apps.who.int/iris/rest/bitstreams/1313227/retrieve

title: Mental Health Interventions in Shelters: Lessons from Hurricane Harvey
source: Natural Hazards Center [University of Colorado at Boulder]
annotation: After Hurricane Harvey hit Houston in 2017, a team of psychiatrists and therapists from Baylor College of Medicine arrived at the George R. Brown Convention Center to help deliver mental health care to those displaced, although information and supplies were limited. The experiences and information gathered can provide useful lessons in how to better prepare shelters to provide mental health services.
authors: Truong, Thanh Truy; Shah, Asim; Goodman, Wayne; Banu, Sophia; Salloum, Alison

title: 130,000 – 210,000 Avoidable COVID-19 Deaths – and Counting – in the U.S
source: National Center for Disaster Preparedness [Columbia University, Earth Institute]
annotation: This 13-page report looks at the staggering and disproportionate nature of COVID-19 fatalities in the United States, which now ranks first in the world in the total number of fatalities, to estimate how many deaths were “avoidable.” It estimates that at least 130,000 deaths and perhaps as many as 210,000 could have been avoided with earlier policy interventions and more robust federal coordination and leadership.
authors: Redlener, Irwin; Sachs, Jeffrey; Hansen, Sean; Hupert, Nathaniel

title: Telehealth for Community-Based Organizations Webinar Series
source: Office of the Assistant Secretary for Preparedness and Response [U.S. Department of Health and Human Services]
annotation: The ASPR At-Risk Individuals Program led this three-part webinar series on implementing telehealth services to address the access and functional needs of at-risk individuals, in partnership with the Department of Housing and Urban Development, during COVID-19 pandemic.

title: NETEC COVID-19 Webinar Series: Containing the Spread of COVID-19 on Inpatient Psychiatric Units
source: National Emerging Special Pathogens Training and Education Center
annotation: This 57-minute webinar discusses effective leadership strategies that will allow for successful management of COVID-19 on inpatient psychiatric units, how to develop policies and procedures that will lead to efficient identification and isolation of cases, and how to identify necessary modifications to unit programming that must be made to prevent the spread of infection.
authors: Tennill, Trish; Lopez, Leonardo
access_notes: Link to presentation slides: https://repository.netecweb.org/files/original/75d455f777383d3b0a352353b88464f0.pdfLink to recording on YouTube: https://youtu.be/lSEFMwMja4o

title: Pandemic’s Effect on the Widening Gap in Mortality Rate Between the U.S. and Peer Countries
annotation: This report compares where COVID-19 falls as a leading cause of death in the U.S. versus peer countries (Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development [OECD] member nations with above median GDP and above median GDP per capita). It finds that COVID-19 mortality rates are the third leading cause of death in the U.S., and that the U.S. nears the top of the list of countries most affected by COVID-19 on a per capita basis, surpassed only by Belgium and the United Kingdom.
authors: Ramirez, Giorlando; Amin, Krutika; Cox, Cynthia

title: COVID-19 Employer Information for Paratransit Operators
source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Office of Infectious Diseases
annotation: This web page provides guidance for paratransit operators about how they can protect their staff and others, and slow the spread of COVID-19.
access_notes: Link to page in Chinese: https://chinese.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/organizations/paratransit-employers.htmlLink to page in Korean: https://korean.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/organizations/paratransit-employers.htmlLink to page in Spanish: https://espanol.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/organizations/paratransit-employers.htmlLink to page in Vietnamese: https://vietnamese.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/organizations/paratransit-employers.htmlLink to page on What Paratransit Operators Need to Know about COVID-19: https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/organizations/paratransit-employees.html

title: Considerations for Monitoring and Evaluation of Mitigation Strategies Implemented in Institutions of Higher Education
source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Office of Infectious Diseases
annotation: This web page, updated on October 21, 2020, provides example evaluation questions, indicators, and data sources to help institutions of higher education, their administrators, public health agencies, and evaluation professionals to monitor and evaluate the implementation and impact of COVID-19 mitigation strategies in institutions of higher education on transmission of SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19.

title: Interim Guidance for Case Investigation and Contact Tracing in Institutions of Higher Education (IHEs)
source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Office of Infectious Diseases
annotation: This web page, updated on October 21, 2020, provides COVID-19 guidance for institutions of higher education on topics that include federal, state, and local legal considerations; roles and responsibilities; ways IHEs can prepare; when a COVID-19 case is suspected or confirmed; and assisting the health department with contact tracing.

title: Considerations for Monitoring and Evaluation of Mitigation Strategies Implemented in K-12 Schools
source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Office of Infectious Diseases
annotation: This resource, updated on October 21, 2020, provides example evaluation questions, indicators, and data sources to help state and local public health and education agencies, school and district administrators, and evaluation professionals monitor and evaluate the implementation and impact of COVID-19 mitigation strategies implemented in K-12 schools on the transmission of SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19.

title: Contact Tracing Workflow in a Non-US Setting
source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Office of Infectious Diseases
annotation: This workflow and additional information, updated on October 21, 2020, are intended to be professionally generated as a job aid for distribution via CDC country offices to local Ministries of Health or National Public Health Institutes with the intent to be given to facilities with frontline healthcare workers doing COVID-19 contact tracing, case investigations, community outreach, or in other ways working with potential contacts.

title: Health Departments: Contact Tracing for COVID-19
source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Office of Infectious Diseases
annotation: This web page, updated on October 21, 2020, provides information for health departments about contact tracing for COVID-19, and a summary of COVID-19-specific practices.

title: Strategies for Protecting K-12 School Staff from COVID-19
source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Office of Infectious Diseases
annotation: The information on this page, updated on October 21, 2020, provides an expanded focus on the health and safety of K-12 school staff during the COVID-19 pandemic. The strategies also provide workplace safety and health information for administrators related to protecting teachers, substitute teachers, paraprofessionals, janitorial/maintenance staff, office staff, school nutrition staff, school nurses/health professionals, school bus drivers and bus aides, coaching staff and athletic trainers, and music, choir, and performing arts teachers.
access_notes: Link to page in Chinese: https://chinese.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/schools-childcare/k-12-staff.htmlLink to page in Korean: https://korean.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/schools-childcare/k-12-staff.htmlLink to page in Spanish: https://espanol.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/schools-childcare/k-12-staff.htmlLink to page in Vietnamese: https://vietnamese.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/schools-childcare/k-12-staff.html

title: Prioritizing Non-Healthcare Worksite Assessments for Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19)
source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Office of Infectious Diseases
annotation: This web page, updated on October 21, 2020, is intended to assist state, tribal, local, and territorial health departments in making decisions about how to allocate limited resources to respond to worksites that report COVID-19-related concerns, complaints, or clusters. In general, COVID-19 clusters in shared housing, detention and correctional facilities, schools, daycares, and youth programs should be considered high priority.
access_notes: A short questionnaire can be customized and used to remotely collect this information from the employer’s human resource, occupational health, safety, or other professional at the worksite. An example is COVID-19 prioritization questions for non-health care worksite assessments by state, tribal, local, and territorial health departments: https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/downloads/php/open-america/Prioritizing-Nonhealthcare-Worksite-Assessments-Checklist.pdf

title: Coronavirus Disease (COVID-19) Screening K-12 Students for Symptoms of COVID-19: Limitations and Considerations
source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Office of Infectious Diseases
annotation: This web page, updated on October 21, 2020, provides guidance to K-12 schools on COVID-19 symptom screening as part of a school reopening process. The guidance detailed here is intended only for students in K-12 school settings.
access_notes: Link to page in Chinese: https://chinese.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/schools-childcare/symptom-screening.htmlLink to page in Korean: https://korean.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/schools-childcare/symptom-screening.htmlLink to page in Spanish: https://espanol.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/schools-childcare/symptom-screening.htmlLink to page in Vietnamese: https://vietnamese.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/schools-childcare/symptom-screening.html

title: Investigating and Responding to COVID-19 Cases in Non-Healthcare Work Settings
source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Office of Infectious Diseases
annotation: Workplaces can present unique challenges for COVID-19 investigation and public health action. The tools on this web page, updated on October 21, 2020, can be used for responding to individual cases and outbreaks in non-healthcare work settings.

title: Testing, Screening, and Outbreak Response for Institutions of Higher Education (IHEs)
source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Office of Infectious Diseases
annotation: This guidance, updated on October 21, 2020, is meant to help college and university administrators protect students, faculty, and staff from COVID-19 infections and slow the spread of the virus.  This document includes considerations for expanded and widespread testing; provides a tiered approach to testing in the context of an outbreak; gives examples of successful entry and periodic screening strategies; and discusses the likelihood of off-campus transmission.
access_notes: Link to page in Chinese: https://chinese.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/colleges-universities/ihe-testing.htmlLink to page in Korean: https://korean.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/colleges-universities/ihe-testing.htmlLink to page in Spanish: https://espanol.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/colleges-universities/ihe-testing.htmlLink to page in Vietnamese: https://vietnamese.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/colleges-universities/ihe-testing.html

title: Interim Considerations for Testing for K-12 School Administrators and Public Health Officials
source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Office of Infectious Diseases
annotation: These interim considerations, updated on October 21, 2020, are for COVID-19 testing in school settings and are intended for K-12 school administrators working in collaboration with their state, tribal, local, and territorial (STLT) public health officials.
access_notes: Link to page in Chinese: https://chinese.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/schools-childcare/k-12-testing.htmlLink to page in Korean: https://korean.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/schools-childcare/k-12-testing.htmlLink to page in Spanish: https://espanol.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/schools-childcare/k-12-testing.htmlLink to page in Vietnamese: https://vietnamese.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/schools-childcare/k-12-testing.html

title: Overview of Testing for SARS-CoV-2 (COVID-19)
source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Office of Infectious Diseases
annotation: This web page, updated on October 21, 2020,  is intended to provide guidance on the appropriate use of testing for SARS-CoV-2 (COVID-19) and does not address decisions regarding payment for or insurance coverage of such testing.

title: COVID-19 Contact Tracing Communications Toolkit for Health Departments
source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Office of Infectious Diseases
annotation: This web page, updated on October 21, 2020, provides communication resources for health departments' COVID-19 contact tracing, under these topics: Main Message, Talking Points, Sample Public Service Announcements, Sample Social Media Posts, and Questions and Answers.
access_notes: Link to page in Spanish: https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/php/contact-tracing-comms-sp.html

title: Identify Strategies to Reduce Spread of COVID-19: Sample Training Plan
source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Office of Infectious Diseases
annotation: This web page, updated on October 21, 2020, provides training resources in these topic areas: Background on COVID-19; COVID-19 disease-specific information; Prevent spread of COVID-19; and Training catalog.

title: Case Investigation and Contact Tracing: Part of a Multi-Pronged Approach to Fight the COVID-19 Pandemic
source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Office of Infectious Diseases
annotation: This web page, updated on October 21, 2020, highlights basic principles of case investigation and contact tracing to stop COVID-19 transmission; detailed guidance for health departments is available.

title: Interim Operational Considerations for Public Health Management of Healthcare Workers Exposed to or Infected with COVID-19: Non-US Healthcare Settings
source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Office of Infectious Diseases
annotation: These operational considerations, updated on October 21, 2020, are intended to be used by healthcare facilities and public health authorities in non-U.S. healthcare settings, particularly focusing on low- and middle-income countries, assisting with the management of healthcare workers exposed to a person with confirmed or suspected COVID-19.
access_notes: Link to page in French: https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/hcp/non-us-settings/public-health-management-hcw-exposed-fr.htmlLink to page in Portuguese: https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/hcp/non-us-settings/profissionais-saude.htmlLink to page in Spanish: https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/hcp/non-us-settings/gestion-de-trabajadores-sanitarios-expuestos.html

title: Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19) Public Health Guidance for Community-Related Exposure
source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Office of Infectious Diseases
annotation: These public health recommendations for community-related exposure to COVID-19 have been updated on October 21, 2020, to accommodate new scientific evidence, evolving epidemiology, and the need to simplify risk assessment.

title: Interim Guidance on Management of Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19) in Correctional and Detention Facilities
source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Office of Infectious Diseases
annotation: This web page, updated October 21, 2020, provides interim guidance specific for correctional facilities and detention centers during the outbreak of COVID-19, to ensure continuation of essential public services and protection of the health and safety of incarcerated and detained persons, staff, and visitors.
access_notes: Link to Resources for Correctional and Detention Facilities: https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/correction-detention/index.htmlLink to page in Chinese: https://chinese.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/correction-detention/guidance-correctional-detention.htmlLink to page in Korean: https://korean.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/correction-detention/guidance-correctional-detention.htmlLink to page in Spanish: https://espanol.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/correction-detention/guidance-correctional-detention.htmlLink to page in Vietnamese: https://vietnamese.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/correction-detention/guidance-correctional-detention.html

title: Diagnostics, Therapeutics, Vaccine Readiness, and Other Health Products for COVID-19
annotation: This 28-page tool has been designed to assess present and surge capacities for the treatment of COVID-19 in health facilities, with a focus on the availability of diagnostics, therapeutics and other health products, vaccine readiness, availability of beds, and space capacities. This tool forms part of a wider suite of health service capacity assessment tools, the harmonized health service capacity assessments in the context of the COVID-19 pandemic.
access_notes: Direct link to document: https://apps.who.int/iris/rest/bitstreams/1313573/retrieve

title: Ensuring a Safe Environment for Patients and Staff in COVID-19 Health-Care Facilities
annotation: This 49-page tool has been designed to assess the structural capacities of hospitals to allow safe COVID-19 case management, maintain the delivery of essential services, and enable surge capacity planning. This tool forms part of a wider suite of health service capacity assessment tools, the harmonized health service capacity assessments in the context of the COVID-19 pandemic.
access_notes: Direct link to document: https://apps.who.int/iris/rest/bitstreams/1313577/retrieve

title: Infection Prevention and Control Health-Care Facility Response for COVID-19
annotation: This 32-page tool has been designed to assess infection prevention and control capacities to respond to COVID-19 in health facilities. This tool forms part of a wider suite of health service capacity assessment tools, the harmonized health service capacity assessments in the context of the COVID-19 pandemic.
access_notes: Direct link to document: https://apps.who.int/iris/rest/bitstreams/1313569/retrieve

title: Continuity of Essential Health Services: Facility Assessment Tool
annotation: This 37-page tool has been designed to help identify health systems bottlenecks in order to monitor and track the continuity of essential health services. It forms part of a wider suite of health service capacity assessment tools, the health service capacity assessments in the context of the COVID-19 pandemic.
access_notes: Direct link to document: https://apps.who.int/iris/rest/bitstreams/1313565/retrieve

title: Legal Challenges to State COVID-19 Orders
source: Association of State and Territorial Health Officials
annotation: This seven-page report examines the legal challenges being made against COVID-19 orders and looks at some of the early litigation results and emerging issues.
access_notes: Direct link to document: https://www.astho.org/ASTHOReports/Legal-Challenges-to-State-COVID-19-Orders/10-20-20/

title: Innovating in the Workplace: Supporting Mental Health of Young People of Color During COVID-19 and Beyond
source: Harvard University, Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health
annotation: This one-hour, six-minute event explores mental health factors employers should consider, along with solutions and strategies for promoting mental health in today’s landscape, and creating a supportive workplace for young people of color.
authors: Martin, Phillip; Akutagawa, Linda; Hooper-Campbell, Damien; Steinberg, Joan; Vinson, Sarah

title: UK Pandemic Preparedness
annotation: This document sets out how the United Kingdom (UK) prepares for and responds to an infectious disease pandemic, particularly a potential outbreak of pandemic influenza; and how exercises carried out as part of pandemic preparedness have informed the UK’s COVID-19 response.

title: Letter of Authorization: binx health At-Home Nasal Swab COVID-19 Sample Collection Kit
annotation: This seven-page letter authorizes the emergency use of the binx health At-Home Nasal Swab COVID-19 Sample Collection Kit. The kit is for use by individuals for self-collection of nasal swab specimens at home, when determined by a healthcare provider to be appropriate based on the results of an online COVID-19 questionnaire and for use only with an in vitro diagnostic (IVD) molecular test for the detection of SARS-CoV-2 RNA that is indicated for use with the binx health At-Home Nasal Swab COVID-19 Sample Collection Kit.
access_notes: Link to EUA summary: https://www.fda.gov/media/143185/downloadLink to Instructions for Use: https://www.fda.gov/media/143186/download

title: Interim Guidance for Case Investigation and Contact Tracing in K-12 Schools
source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Office of Infectious Diseases
annotation: This web page aims to highlight potential collaboration between health officials and K-12 school administrators to facilitate effective COVID-19 case investigation and contact tracing. Topics are Overview; Background; Federal, state, and local legal considerations; Roles and responsibilities; Ways schools can prepare; When a COVID-19 case is suspected or confirmed; and Assisting the health department with contact tracing.
access_notes: Link to page in Chinese: https://chinese.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/schools-childcare/contact-tracing.htmlLink to page in Korean: https://korean.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/schools-childcare/contact-tracing.htmlLink to page in Spanish: https://espanol.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/schools-childcare/contact-tracing.htmlLink to page in Vietnamese: https://vietnamese.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/schools-childcare/contact-tracing.html

title: SARS-CoV-2 Testing Strategy: Considerations for Non-Healthcare Workplaces
source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Office of Infectious Diseases
annotation: The purpose of this web page is to provide employers with strategies for consideration of incorporating testing for SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19, into a workplace COVID-19 preparedness, response, and control plan.
access_notes: Link to page in Chinese: https://chinese.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/organizations/testing-non-healthcare-workplaces.htmlLink to page in Korean: https://korean.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/organizations/testing-non-healthcare-workplaces.htmlLink to page in Spanish: https://espanol.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/organizations/testing-non-healthcare-workplaces.htmlLink to page in Vietnamese: https://vietnamese.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/organizations/testing-non-healthcare-workplaces.html

title: Distributing a COVID-19 Vaccine Across the U.S.: A Look at Key Issues
annotation: This issue brief details the key issues and challenges of distributing a COVID-19 vaccine in the U.S., including Funding for Vaccine Distribution; Supply, Logistics, and Monitoring; Federal, State, and Local Authority Over Vaccination Requirements; Insurance Coverage and Out-of-Pocket Costs; Addressing Racial and Ethnic Disparities; and Communication and Trust.
authors: Michaud, Josh; Kates, Jennifer

title: Fact Sheet for Healthcare Personnel: Zoe-Ann Decontamination System for Decontaminating Compatible N95 Respirators
annotation: This three-page fact sheet informs healthcare providers of the significant known and potential risks and benefits of the emergency use of decontaminated, compatible N95 respirators. These compatible N95 respirators have been decontaminated using the Zoe-Ann Decontamination System.
access_notes: Link to Letter of Authorization: https://www.fda.gov/media/143149/downloadLink to Instructions for Healthcare Personnel: https://www.fda.gov/media/143151/downloadLink to Instructions for Healthcare Facilities: https://www.fda.gov/media/143152/download

title: Cleaning, Disinfection, and Hand Hygiene in Schools: A Toolkit for School Administrators
source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Office of Infectious Diseases
annotation: This guidance, updated on October 20, 2020, is intended to aid school administrators as they consider how to protect the health, safety, and well-being of students, teachers, other school staff, families, and communities, and prepare for educating students this fall. It details the Importance of cleaning, disinfection, and hand hygiene.
access_notes: Link to page in Chinese: https://chinese.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/schools-childcare/clean-disinfect-hygiene.htmlLink to page in Korean: https://korean.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/schools-childcare/clean-disinfect-hygiene.htmlLink to page in Spanish: https://espanol.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/schools-childcare/clean-disinfect-hygiene.htmlLink to page in Vietnamese: https://vietnamese.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/schools-childcare/clean-disinfect-hygiene.html

title: Testing Strategy for Coronavirus (COVID-19) in High-Density Critical Infrastructure Workplaces after a COVID-19 Case Is Identified
source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Office of Infectious Diseases
annotation: This web page, updated on October 20, 2020, presents different COVID-19 testing strategy options for exposed co-workers when public health organizations and employers determine COVID-19 testing is needed to help support existing disease control measures. Such strategies can aid in identifying infectious individuals with the goal of reducing transmission of SARS-CoV-2 in the workplace.
access_notes: Link to page in Chinese: https://chinese.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/worker-safety-support/hd-testing.htmlLink to page in Korean: https://korean.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/worker-safety-support/hd-testing.htmlLink to page in Spanish: https://espanol.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/worker-safety-support/hd-testing.htmlLink to page in Vietnamese: https://vietnamese.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/worker-safety-support/hd-testing.html

title: Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA): Emergency Temporary Standards (ETS) and COVID-19
annotation: The Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) does not currently have a specific standard that protects healthcare or other workers from airborne or aerosol transmission of disease or diseases transmitted by airborne droplets. This 31-page report, updated on October 20, 2020, describes how some in Congress, and some groups representing healthcare and other workers, are calling on OSHA to promulgate an emergency temporary standard (ETS) to protect workers from exposure to SARS-Cov-2, the virus that causes coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19).
authors: Szymendera, Scott

title: Trends in Overall and Non-COVID-19 Hospital Admissions
annotation: This report analyzed trends in total hospital admissions, and then separately analyzed non-COVID-19 admissions by patient sex, age, and region. It calculated actual admissions as a share of total predicted admissions in 2020 based on trends from past years.
authors: Heist, Tyler; Schwartz, Karyn; Butler, Sam

title: Updated Advice on Hospital Antibiotic Management and Antimicrobial Stewardship in the Context of the COVID-19 Pandemic
annotation: This two-page document provides recommendations that have been agreed upon by infections specialists from across Scotland to support National Health Service boards with local clinical practice and to maintain antimicrobial stewardship during the COVID-19 pandemic.

title: Advice on Management of People with Respiratory Infections Presenting in the Community During the COVID-19 Pandemic
annotation: As the COVID-19 pandemic continues, it is critical that local antibiotic treatment guidelines are followed and that unnecessary antibiotic use is minimized. This one-page document provides guidelines for antibiotic treatment.

title: Confronting Urgent Threats to Human Health and Society: COVID-19 and Climate Change (NAM Annual Meeting)
annotation: This web page provides recordings and presentation slides from the 2020 National Academy of Medicine Annual Meeting, which focused on the state of the COVID-19 pandemic: virus emergence, the impact of the pandemic, and U.S. and global preparedness and response; climate change and human health: navigating environmental, societal, and individual impacts; and responding to global crises: future directions in science and policymaking to address complex threats to society.
authors: Gates, Bill; Fauci, Anthony S.; Gupta, Sanjay; Ihekweazu, Chikwe; Lurie, Nicole

title: Duration of Isolation and Precautions for Adults with COVID-19
source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Office of Infectious Diseases
annotation: Accumulating evidence supports ending isolation and precautions for persons with COVID-19 using a symptom-based strategy. This guidance, updated on October 19, 2020, incorporates recent evidence to inform the duration of isolation and precautions recommended to prevent transmission of SARS-CoV-2 to others, while limiting unnecessary prolonged isolation and unnecessary use of laboratory testing resources.

title: Incorporation of GIS (Geographic Information Systems) Technologies in Emergency Preparedness and Response
source: National Center for Disaster Preparedness [Columbia University, Earth Institute]
annotation: This 32-page document discusses how geographic information systems (GIS) can enable public health agency staff to visualize spatial information in new ways, so that they can become better planners and problem solvers, particularly in the areas of disaster preparedness and response. It covers online GIS data resources, constraints to using GIS in public health, best practices, competencies needed for using GIS, and public health research incorporating GIS technologies.
authors: Chandler, Thomas
access_notes: Direct link to document: https://academiccommons.columbia.edu/doi/10.7916/D8W384MW/download

title: Interim Considerations for Health Departments for SARS-CoV-2 Testing in Homeless Shelters and Encampments
source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Office of Infectious Diseases
annotation: The information on this web page, updated on October 19, 2020, is meant to assist health departments and homeless service providers in making decisions on the appropriate use of COVID-19 testing, including testing asymptomatic individuals with recent known or suspected exposure to SARS-CoV-2 to control transmission.
access_notes: Link to page in Chinese: https://chinese.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/homeless-shelters/testing.htmlLink to page in Korean: https://korean.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/homeless-shelters/testing.htmlLink to page in Spanish: https://espanol.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/homeless-shelters/testing.htmlLink to page in Vietnamese: https://vietnamese.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/homeless-shelters/testing.html

title: COVID-19 Infection Prevention and Control for Primary Care, Including General Practitioner Practices, Dental Clinics and Pharmacy Settings: First Update
source: European Union, European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control
annotation: This 12-page document, updated on October 19, 2020, provides guidance on infection prevention and control to healthcare providers, general practitioner offices, primary care clinics, dental offices/clinics, and pharmacies in the European Union/European Economic Area in order to prevent COVID-19 infection.
access_notes: Direct link to document: https://www.ecdc.europa.eu/sites/default/files/documents/covid-19-infection-prevention-primary-care-dental-clinics-pharmacy-october-2020.pdfLink to related infographic: https://www.ecdc.europa.eu/en/publications-data/infographic-infection-prevention-and-control-primary-care

title: Frequently Asked Questions: Right of Reference to the CDC Influenza SARS-CoV-2 (Flu SC2) Performance Data for Manufacturers and Test Developers
source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Office of Infectious Diseases
annotation: This web page for laboratories provides answers to frequently asked questions about the CDC Influenza SARS-CoV-2 (Flu SC2) performance data for manufacturers and test developers.

title: Resources for Laboratories Working on Coronavirus (COVID-19)
source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Office of Infectious Diseases
annotation: This web page provides resources for laboratories working on (COVID-19), including about diagnostic tests, using antibody tests, and pooling procedures.

title: Testing Guidance for Clinicians When SARS-CoV-2 and Influenza Viruses are Co-circulating
source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Office of Infectious Diseases
annotation: This web page provides an algorithm for clinicians regarding outpatient clinic or emergency department patients with acute respiratory illness symptoms (with or without fever) when SARS-CoV-2 and flu viruses are co-circulating.
access_notes: Link to page in Spanish: https://espanol.cdc.gov/flu/professionals/diagnosis/testing-guidance-for-clinicians.htmLink to Testing Guidance for Outpatient Clinic or Emergency Department Patients with Acute Respiratory Illness Symptoms (With or Without Fever) Not Requiring Hospital Admission:  https://www.cdc.gov/flu/professionals/diagnosis/testing-guidance-for-outpatient.htmLink to page in Spanish: https://espanol.cdc.gov/flu/professionals/diagnosis/testing-guidance-for-outpatient.htmLink to Testing Guidance Patients with Acute Respiratory Illness Symptoms Requiring Hospital Admission (With or Without Fever): https://www.cdc.gov/flu/professionals/diagnosis/testing-guidance-for-clinicians-hospitaized.htmLink to page in Spanish: https://espanol.cdc.gov/flu/professionals/diagnosis/testing-guidance-for-clinicians-hospitaized.htm

title: Disasters and Religion App
annotation: This app helps disaster responders better serve America’s diverse religious communities and build partnerships with religious leaders, with easily accessible religious literacy and competency information on 27 unique religions. It was created by the National Disaster Interfaiths Network (NDIN), New York Disaster Interfaith Services (NYDIS), and the University of Southern California Center for Religion and Civic Culture (CRCC).
access_notes: Link to app from the App Store: https://apps.apple.com/us/app/disasters-and-religions/id1513405416Link to app from Google Play: https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.crcc&hl=en_US&gl=US

title: NETEC COVID-19 Webinar Series: Pediatric Perspectives During a Pandemic
source: National Emerging Special Pathogens Training and Education Center
annotation: This 54-minute webinar describes the epidemiology of acute COVID-19, including post-infectious manifestations and the unique aspects of caring for children during a pandemic. It also discusses the features of multi-system inflammatory syndrome in children (MIS-C) and how to devise a diagnostic and acute management plan and integrate potential post-recovery complications into the development of follow-up plans for a child with MIS-C.
authors: Grindle, Amanda; Shayne, Andi; Jaggio, Preeti; Oster, Matthew
access_notes: Link to video on YouTube: https://youtu.be/mseYyxUrMk4Link to presentation slides: https://repository.netecweb.org/files/original/840a5b3eb0d83e90f0f487520d270e08.pdf

title: Emergency Alert System (EAS) and All-Hazard Warnings
annotation: This 14-page document describes the organization and administration of the Emergency Alert System, NOAA Weather Radio, All-Hazard Warning Technology, and the Commercial Mobile Alert System. It also summarizes two 2009 Congressional initiatives concerning emergency preparedness.
authors: Moore, Linda K.

title: Hurricane Suiter Emergency Support Function 6, Mass Care and Emergency Assistance After Action Report
annotation: This 18-page document is the after action report for a hurricane exercise from May 28-June 3, 2009. Hurricane Suiter was one of the most intense and demanding hurricane exercises ever conducted in the state. The mass care portion of the exercise was one of the largest and most complex ever conducted in the nation.

title: COVID-19 Case Investigation and Contact Tracing in Non-Healthcare Workplaces: How Employers Can Assist Health Departments
annotation: Health departments are responsible for leading case investigations, contact tracing, and outbreak investigations. When a COVID-19 case is identified that impacts a workplace, the health department may ask the employer for help. This web page provides tips to ensure employers and their employees are prepared to assist if contacted by the health department.
access_notes: Link to page in Chinese: https://chinese.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/contact-tracing-nonhealthcare-workplaces/FS-Employers.htmlLink to page in Korean: https://korean.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/contact-tracing-nonhealthcare-workplaces/FS-Employers.htmlLink to page in Spanish: https://espanol.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/contact-tracing-nonhealthcare-workplaces/FS-Employers.htmlLink to page in Vietnamese: https://vietnamese.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/contact-tracing-nonhealthcare-workplaces/FS-Employers.html

title: Operational Considerations for Influenza Surveillance in the WHO European Region During COVID-19: Interim Guidance
source: European Union, European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control
annotation: This 11-page document outlines operational considerations for how to support the continuity of national influenza surveillance systems and public health laboratories for the epidemiological and virological surveillance for influenza in the 2020–2021 season during the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. It also describes how these systems might be used to contribute to COVID-19 surveillance.
access_notes: Direct link to document: https://www.ecdc.europa.eu/sites/default/files/documents/Joint-influenza-interim-guidance.pdf

title: Guidance for Discharge and Ending of Isolation of People with COVID-19
source: European Union, European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control
annotation: This seven-page document provides guidance for planning the discharge and ending of isolation of COVID-19 patients. It is provided in the context of all European Union/European Economic Area (EU/EEA) countries and the United Kingdom continuing to experience varying degrees of community transmission of SARS-CoV-2.
access_notes: Direct link to document: https://www.ecdc.europa.eu/sites/default/files/documents/Guidance-for-discharge-and-ending-of-isolation-of-people-with-COVID-19.pdf

title: Interim Guidance for Implementing Home Care of People Not Requiring Hospitalization for Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19)
source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Office of Infectious Diseases
annotation: This interim guidance, updated on October 16, 2020, is for staff at local and state health departments, infection prevention and control professionals, and healthcare personnel who are coordinating the home care and isolation of people with confirmed or suspected COVID-19 infection, including persons under investigation.
access_notes: Link to page in Spanish: https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/hcp/guidance-home-care-es.html

title: Information for Laboratories about Coronavirus (COVID-19)
source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Office of Infectious Diseases
annotation: This web page, updated on October 16, 2020, provides COVID-19 resources for laboratories, including about diagnostics tests, CDC lab work, publications, and alerts and advisories.

title: Testing Guidelines for Nursing Homes: Interim SARS-CoV-2 Testing Guidelines for Nursing Home Residents and Healthcare Personnel
source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Office of Infectious Diseases
annotation: This web page, updated on October 16, 2020, is intended to provide guidance on the appropriate use of COVID-19 testing among nursing home residents and does not dictate the determination of payment decisions or insurance coverage of such testing, except as may be otherwise referenced (or prescribed) by another entity or federal or state agency.

title: Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19): Schools and Childcare Programs: Plan, Prepare, and Respond
source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Office of Infectious Diseases
annotation: This web page, updated on October 16, 2020, provides guidance for school and program administrators, parents, and caregivers, with sections on Reopening: Decision-Making Indicators, Printable Posters and Graphics, and additional resources.
access_notes: Link to page in Chinese: https://chinese.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/schools-childcare/index.htmlLink to page in Korean: https://korean.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/schools-childcare/index.htmlLink to page in Spanish: https://espanol.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/schools-childcare/index.htmlLink to page in Vietnamese: https://vietnamese.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/schools-childcare/index.htmlLink to Considerations for School Closure: https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/downloads/considerations-for-school-closure.pdf Link to Interim Guidance for Administrators of U.S. K-12 Schools and Childcare Programs, including a decision tree: https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/schools-childcare/guidance-for-schools.htmlLink to Supplemental Guidance For Child Care Programs That Remain Open: https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/schools-childcare/guidance-for-childcare.htmlLink to COVID-19 Stakeholder Call: Camps and Youth Programs: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8l5Kw7IfIoM&feature=youtu.beLink to COVID-19 Stakeholder Call: Schools and Childcare Programs: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=o9YXxl-79Zs&feature=youtu.be

title: Colleges, Universities, and Higher Learning: Plan, Prepare, and Respond
source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Office of Infectious Diseases
annotation: This web page, updated on October 16, 2020, provides COVID-19 guidance resources for administrators, faculty, and staff of institutes of higher education, including when to quarantine.
access_notes: Link to page in Chinese: https://chinese.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/colleges-universities/index.htmlLink to page in Korean: https://korean.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/colleges-universities/index.htmlLink to page in Spanish: https://espanol.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/colleges-universities/index.htmlLink to page in Vietnamese: https://vietnamese.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/colleges-universities/index.html

title: Supply Shortages Impacting COVID-19 and Non-COVID Testing
annotation: ASM has partnered with the Association of Supply Chain Management to develop a survey to collect testing supplies status for COVID-19 tests, as well as other microbiological tests, to highlight, and ultimately alleviate, these supply chain issues. This web page will provide the survey findings each week on the most recent shortages of medium, reagents, collection devices, and consumables that are significantly impacting day-to-day testing for both COVID-19 and other infectious diseases, along with week-over-week longitudinal changes.

title: SARS-CoV-2 mRNA Vaccine Development Enabled by Prototype Pathogen Preparedness
annotation: With a new infectious disease threat at hand, scientists at the NIH swiftly developed a vaccine candidate against the novel coronavirus that causes COVID-19. The pre-clinical effort for a fast, reliable, and universal vaccine was driven in part by the speaker in this one-hour presentation.
authors: Corbett, Kizzmekia

title: Letter of Authorization: EmpowerDX At-Home COVID-19 PCR Test Kit
annotation: This seven-page letter authorizes the emergency use of the EmpowerDX At-Home COVID-19 PCR Test Kit for use by individuals to self-collect nasal swabs at home, when determined by a healthcare provider to be appropriate based on the results of an online COVID-19 questionnaire, and for use only with in vitro diagnostic (IVD) molecular tests for the detection of SARS-CoV-2 RNA that are indicated for use with the EmpowerDX At-Home COVID-19 PCR Test Kit.
access_notes: Link to EUA Summary: https://www.fda.gov/media/143064/downloadLink to Instructions for Use: https://www.fda.gov/media/143065/download

title: COVID-19 and the U.S. Criminal Justice System
source: Center for Health Security [Johns Hopkins University, Bloomberg School of Public Health]
annotation: This 33-page report summarizes the current state and future projections of the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States, details the impact that the pandemic has already had on the U.S. criminal justice system, and provides evidence-based recommendations on how to reduce COVID-19 risks to people in the system.
authors: Watson, Crystal; Warmbrod, Kelsey; Vahey, Rachel; Cicero, Anita; Inglesby, Thomas V.
access_notes: Direct link to document: https://www.centerforhealthsecurity.org/our-work/pubs_archive/pubs-pdfs/2020/20201015-covid-19-criminal-justice-system.pdfLink to webinar for report launch: https://youtu.be/YaQQ8pNznUg

title: Impact of the COVID-19 Pandemic on Outpatient Care: Visits Return to Prepandemic Levels, but Not for All Providers and Patients
annotation: This report details how visits for outpatient care, which had fallen nearly 60 percent in April, have returned in the past month to the levels prior to the COVID-19 pandemic. While outpatient visits overall have rebounded, there is a lot of variation among providers.
authors: Mehrotra, Ateev; Chernew, Michael; Linetsky, David; Hatch, Hilary; Cutler, David

title: Communicate Better to Protect Your Community in a Crisis!
source: University at Albany Center for Public Health Preparedness [State University of New York]
annotation: This hour-long presentation explains how to effectively communicate with the public before, during, and after an emergency.

title: Living with COVID-19: A Dynamic Review of the Evidence Around Ongoing COVID-19 Symptoms (Often Called Long COVID)
annotation: This rapid and dynamic review draws on the lived experience of COVID-19 patients and expert consensus, as well as published evidence, to better understand the impact of ongoing effects of COVID-19, how health and social care services should respond, and what future research questions might be.

title: COVID-19 Response Assistance Field Team Observations
source: Office of the Assistant Secretary for Preparedness and Response [U.S. Department of Health and Human Services]
annotation: ASPR’s COVID-19 Response Assistance Field Team (CRAFT) has spent the last several months traveling the country engaging with local communities and supporting their COVID-19 response efforts in a variety of areas (e.g., K-12 schools and institutes of higher education, critical infrastructure businesses, and outreach to at-risk populations). This TRACIE (Technical Resources, Assistance Center, and Information Exchange) landing page provides links to CRAFT Resource Collections.

title: External Quality Assessment (EQA) of Performance of Laboratories Participating in the European Antimicrobial Resistance Surveillance Network (EARS-Net), 2019
source: European Union, European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control
annotation: This 26-page report provides an analysis of the external quality assessment (EQA) for the antimicrobial susceptibility testing (AST) performance of laboratories participating in the European Antimicrobial Resistance Surveillance Network (EARS-Net) in 2019.
access_notes: Direct link to document: https://www.ecdc.europa.eu/sites/default/files/documents/antibiotic-resistance-external-quality-assessment-lab-peformance-EARS-Net-2019.pdf

title: Fact Sheet for Healthcare Providers: LumiraDx SARS-CoV-2 RNA STAR Complete
annotation: This three-page fact sheet informs healthcare providers of the significant known and potential risks and benefits of the emergency use of the LumiraDx SARS-CoV-2 RNA STAR Complete. The LumiraDx SARS-CoV-2 RNA STAR Complete is authorized for use with respiratory specimens collected from individuals suspected of COVID-19 by their healthcare provider.
access_notes: Link to Fact Sheet for Patients: https://www.fda.gov/media/143061/downloadLink to Letter of Authorization: https://www.fda.gov/media/143059/downloadLink to Instructions for Use: https://www.fda.gov/media/143062/download

title: Letter of Authorization: OMNIgene·ORAL OM-505 and OME-505 (OMNIgene·ORAL) Saliva Collection Devices
annotation: This six-page letter authorizes the emergency use of the OMNIgene·ORAL OM-505 and OME-505 (OMNIgene·ORAL) saliva collection devices, which are intended for use by individuals to collect, stabilize, and maintain during transport, saliva specimens suspected of containing SARS-CoV-2 ribonucleic acid (RNA).
