source: Alliance for Child Protection in Humanitarian Action
annotation: This 71-page document provides practical guidance to actors in humanitarian and development contexts on the adaptations and considerations needed to support children who are either currently in alternative care or are going into an alternative care placement during the COVID-19 pandemic.
access_notes: Direct link to document: https://www.alliancecpha.org/en/system/tdf/library/attachments/guidanceforalternativecarecovid19_0.pdf?file=1&type=node&id=40248

title: Collection: Chemical Hazards and Poisons Report
annotation: These documents provide chemical hazards and poisons information for health and emergency professionals involved in chemical incident response and preparedness, including first line responders such as fire and ambulance services.

title: Health and Retirement Study
annotation: As a longitudinal study with rich measurement across a large number of social, health, and economic domains, the Health and Retirement Study (HRS) was designed to capture the impact of unexpected societal events, even without additional measurement specific to the event. To complement these longitudinal measures, HRS has developed several areas of content specifically in response to the coronavirus pandemic designed to dovetail with existing assessment. Information on lifestyle and psychosocial functioning is collected through a self-administered questionnaire (SAQ). Additional questions in the psychosocial SAQ were added to the 2020 wave of data collection. These questions obtain information on lifestyle, personal relationships, work, and feelings in response to the pandemic. These questions cover five subtopics: 1) pandemic-specific concerns related to health, finances, friends and family, and the future; 2) changes in social contact with family and friends, including social support given and received and changes in relationship quality; 3) impact on activities including pandemic-specific behaviors such as wearing a mask, washing hands, social distancing, and using hand sanitizer; 4) additional questions about work status that indicate if the respondent was an essential worker and whether or not they could work at home during the pandemic; and 5) emotional well-being, resilience, and coping during the pandemic.Population: Adults onlyLength: 77 questionsMode of Administration: Online (e.g., computer-assisted interview)Administered by: Professional InterviewerSelf AdministeredLanguage(s): EnglishHealth and Retirement Study: Core Interview COVID-19 Module: Full Survey https://www.phenxtoolkit.org/toolkit_content/PDF/UMich_HRS_Module.pdfDirect Experience of COVID-19: General Symptoms; Diagnosis https://www.phenxtoolkit.org/toolkit_content/PDF/UMich_HRS_Module_Experience.pdfHealth Care Access (general): Health Care https://www.phenxtoolkit.org/toolkit_content/PDF/UMich_HRS_Module_Health_Care.pdfEconomic Impact Payments: Economic Insecurity https://www.phenxtoolkit.org/toolkit_content/PDF/UMich_HRS_Module_Payments.pdfWork and Business: Employment; Economic Impact https://www.phenxtoolkit.org/toolkit_content/PDF/UMich_HRS_Module_Employment.pdfLiving Arrangements: Housing Security; Home Life https://www.phenxtoolkit.org/toolkit_content/PDF/UMich_HRS_Module_Living_Arrangements.pdfCaregiving: Community Assistance https://www.phenxtoolkit.org/toolkit_content/PDF/UMich_HRS_Module_Caregiving.pdf
access_notes: Free/Publicly AvailableWeb page for questionnaires: https://hrs.isr.umich.edu/data-products/covid-19 Web page for documentation, including a codebook: https://hrs.isr.umich.edu/documentationAvailable Formats: PDFContact Information: David WeirDirector of Health and Retirement Studydweir@umich.edu

title: Preprints and Peer Review in a Pandemic
source: Johns Hopkins University, Bloomberg School of Public Health
annotation: The COVID-19 pandemic has transformed the research publishing landscape as scientists investigate and try to understand the novel coronavirus SARS-CoV-2 and the complex disease it causes. This has led to unprecedented volume and speed in scientific publishing. This one-hour, 15-minute video presents speakers who discuss the risks and rewards of scientific publishing in this urgent and fast-paced environment.
authors: Bauchner, Howard; Gurley, Emily; Krumholz, Harlan; Zimmer, Carl; Kirk, Gregory

title: From Grief to Endurance: Spiritual and Mental Health for the Long Haul
annotation: This one-hour webinar presents a panel of experts who offer insight for addressing spiritual and mental health needs for the long haul during the COVID-19 pandemic, and understanding why it's important that we acknowledge our collective grief and look toward endurance.
authors: Aten, Jamie; Annan, Kent; Martin, Nicole; Louissaint, Nicolette; Monroe, Philip

title: Antigen-Detection in the Diagnosis of SARS-CoV-2 Infection Using Rapid Immunoassays
annotation: Acknowledging the inadequacy of current data on the performance and operational utility of tests using a lateral flow immunoassay (also called an RDT) that gives results in < 30 minutes, this nine-page document seeks to provide guidance to countries on considerations for integration into COVID-19 outbreak management programs.
access_notes: Direct link to document: https://apps.who.int/iris/rest/bitstreams/1302653/retrieve

title: Diagnostic Testing for SARS-CoV-2
annotation: This 20-page document provides interim guidance to laboratories and other stakeholders involved in diagnostics for severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2).  It covers the main considerations for specimen collection, nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT), antigen (Ag), antibody (Ab) detection and quality assurance.
access_notes: Direct link to document: https://apps.who.int/iris/rest/bitstreams/1302661/retrieve

title: Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) Illustrated Guide for Community and Social Care Settings
annotation: This eight-page guidance on personal protective equipment (PPE), updated on September 11, 2020, is for health and social care workers working in the community during this period of sustained transmission of COVID-19.
access_notes: Direct link to document: https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/925605/PHE_PPE_illustrated_guide_for_community_and_social_care_settings_OCT_2020.pdf

title: Guidance for Children and Families Involved with the Child Welfare System During the COVID-19 Pandemic
annotation: This web page, updated on September 11, 2020, provides guidance during the COVID-19 pandemic for pediatricians and others who care for children in the child welfare system that affirms that a stable home and caregiver are important to nurturing a child’s development and preventing trauma that can affect a child across the lifespan.

title: Coronavirus Disease (COVID-19) Training for Healthcare Professionals
source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Office of Infectious Diseases
annotation: This web page, updated on September 11, 2020, provides links to COVID-19 training for healthcare professionals under these topics: Clinical Care and Infection Control, Personal Protective Equipment (PPE), Nonpharmaceutical Interventions (NPIs), Emergency Preparedness and Response, and COVID-19 Trainings on TRAIN.

title: Additional COVID-19 Guidance for Caregivers of People Living with Dementia in Community Settings
source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Office of Infectious Diseases
annotation: Given the risks that older adults face from both COVID-19 and dementia, CDC is providing this additional guidance, updated on September 11, 2020, to caregivers of adults with Alzheimer’s disease and other types of dementia to reduce the spread of COVID-19 and to help them manage their patients’ physical and mental well-being, as well as their own well-being.
access_notes: Link to guidance in Chinese: https://chinese.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/need-extra-precautions/caregivers-dementia.htmlLink to guidance in Korean: https://korean.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/need-extra-precautions/caregivers-dementia.htmlLink to guidance in Spanish: https://espanol.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/need-extra-precautions/caregivers-dementia.htmlLink to guidance in Vietnamese: https://vietnamese.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/need-extra-precautions/caregivers-dementia.html

title: Safe Handling of Bodies of Deceased Persons with Suspected or Confirmed COVID-19
source: BC Centre for Disease Control [Government of British Columbia]
annotation: This provincial guidance, updated on September 11, 2020, will help to assist people who may handle the bodies of deceased persons during the COVID-19 pandemic. This guidance has been developed to ensure that the deceased are treated with sensitivity, dignity, and respect, and that people who come into contact with the deceased are protected from infection.

title: Implementing Safety Practices for Critical Infrastructure Workers Who May Have Had Exposure to a Person with Suspected or Confirmed COVID-19
source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Office of Infectious Diseases
annotation: To ensure continuity of operations of essential functions, this interim guidance, updated on September 11, 2020, advises that critical infrastructure workers may be permitted to continue work following potential exposure to COVID-19, provided they remain asymptomatic and additional precautions are implemented to protect them and the community.
access_notes: Link to guidance in a PDF file: https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/downloads/critical-workers-implementing-safety-practices.pdfLink to guidance in Spanish: https://espanol.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/critical-workers/implementing-safety-practices.htmlLink to guidance in Vietnamese: https://vietnamese.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/critical-workers/implementing-safety-practices.html

title: Standard Operating Procedure (SOP) for Triage of Suspected COVID-19 Patients in non-US Healthcare Settings
source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Office of Infectious Diseases
annotation: This COVID-19 triage resource, updated on September 11, 2020, includes edits to clarify how healthcare workers can protect themselves during triage, and updates to the triage algorithm to allow for fever (>38°C) OR history of fever.

title: Contingency Planning for Marine Pollution Preparedness and Response
source: United Kingdom Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs
annotation: This 74-page document from the Maritime and Coastguard Agency, updated on September 11, 2020, provides guidelines for harbor authorities and oil handling facilities in relation to oil pollution. It provides guidance from the Nature Conservation Agencies, Environmental Regulator, and Fisheries Departments, and recommends a quantified and risk-based approach to contingency planning.
access_notes: Direct link to document: https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/916871/OPRC_GUIDELINES_DRAFT_SEP_2020_Changesaccepted.pdf

title: Mitigating the Impact of COVID-19 on Control of Vaccine-Preventable Diseases
source: World Health Organization, Regional Office for Europe
annotation: The COVID-19 pandemic may cause disruptions in the provision of routine immunization services, but this risk can be reduced if national immunization programs take measures to minimize service interruptions, as well as plan for and implement catch-up vaccination. This 11-page document aims to support national decision-makers and  immunization programs ineffectively integrating the necessary response measures into existing programmatic areas.
access_notes: Direct link to document: https://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/handle/10665/334248/WHO-EURO-2020-1086-40832-55187-eng.pdf?sequence=1&isAllowed=y

title: Advancing the Science of Real-World Data to Address the COVID-19 Pandemic
annotation: This one-hour presentation discusses the potential for diverse, real-world data sources such as electronic health records, insurance claims, patient registries, and lab results to further inform the science-based, all-of-America response to the COVID-19 public health emergency. These data can inform ongoing work to evaluate potential therapies, vaccines, or diagnostics for COVID-19.
authors: Abernethy, Amy

title: COVID-19 Pandemic Impact on Patients, Families and Individuals in Recovery from Substance Use Disorders
annotation: This 22-page report sheds light on the experiences of patients and impacted individuals with a substance use disorder on the emotional and health consequences of COVID-19, overdose rates, and barriers in safely accessing care during the pandemic.
authors: Hulsey, Jessica; Mellis, Alexandra; Kelly, Braeden
access_notes: Direct link to document: https://54817af5-b764-42ff-a7e2-97d6e4449c1a.usrfiles.com/ugd/54817a_7ff82ba57ba14491b888d9d2e068782f.pdf

title: ADA (Americans with Disabilities Act) National Network Learning Session: Listos California Emergency Preparedness Campaign - An Innovative Community Based Approach to Disaster Preparedness
source: ADA [Americans with Disabilities Act] National Network
annotation: This one-hour, 18-minute webinar highlights the efforts of this ground-breaking $50 million approach to whole community preparedness. It discusses how with centering the community first, preparedness efforts are more accessible, relevant, and effective to target populations.
authors: Baker, Karen; Knighten, Justin
access_notes: Link to recording: https://us02web.zoom.us/rec/play/ixO0Bat1cvVFZKxDxI78W42EmjbR71yI_LGcH64C_VNKFeY2zsSJN8cDo2iQrCjRC8uBxsS0zaRR_mJ-.0sFTN6l6hFj5KDjO?continueMode=true&_x_zm_rtaid=bgb0uq4HTnKrWqCydw_8_Q.1601324691269.98b5a4dc573df9d81ea40e5a6c3b558d&_x_zm_rhtaid=406Link to presentation slides: https://www.adapresentations.org/doc/9_10_20/Listos%20California%20Emergency%20Preparedness%20Campaign.pdfLink to transcript: https://www.adapresentations.org/doc/9_10_20/Transcript%2009-10-20.pdf

title: Beyond the Case Count: The Wide-Ranging Disparities of COVID-19 in the United States
annotation: This report provides analysis of a survey that shows that Americans’ experience of economic hardship, their mental health concerns, and their opinion of government leaders during the COVID-19 pandemic varied by race, gender, and income.
authors: Getachew, Yaphet; Zephyrin, Laurie; Abrams, Melinda; Shah, Arnav; Lewis, Corinne

title: Guidance for Institutions of Higher Education with Students Participating in International Travel or Study Abroad Programs
source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Office of Infectious Diseases
annotation: This guidance is for Institutes of Higher Education with international travel or study abroad programs, who should consider postponing or canceling these student international travel programs.
access_notes: Link to page in Chinese: https://chinese.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/student-foreign-travel.htmlLink to page in Korean: https://korean.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/student-foreign-travel.htmlLink to page in Spanish: https://espanol.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/student-foreign-travel.htmlLink to page in Vietnamese: https://vietnamese.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/student-foreign-travel.html

title: Pandemic Forum: COVID-19’s Impact on Geopolitical Risk and Global Resiliency
source: Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars
annotation: This one-hour, 51-minute forum features healthcare professionals, former national security leaders, and risk management executives who discuss the wide reaching impacts of health and the COVID-19 pandemic on geopolitical risks and considerations for public and private resiliency.
authors: Weir, Tim; Johnson, Joyce; Wolff, Evan; Manyak, Michael; Chudnovskiy, Anatoliy

title: Opioid Addiction – Incarceration Pipeline: A National Health Crisis Compounded in Rural Areas
annotation: This 50-minute webinar highlights the connections between opioids and other types of substance misuse, incarceration, and chronic health conditions/early death of those who spend time in jail/prison. The discussion includes information about the linkages between adverse childhood experiences (ACEs), opioid misuse, chronic health conditions, health disparities, criminal activity, and imprisonment across the country.
authors: Young, David
access_notes: Link to presentation slides: https://www.canr.msu.edu/ncrcrd/uploads/files/NCRCRD%20Webinar%20PPT%20SEPT%2010%202020%20FINAL.pdf

title: Ebola Outbreaks in the Democratic Republic of Congo: Emergencies or Enduring Threat?
annotation: This 15-page report discusses how the prolonged battle to contain the Ebola outbreak in eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC), coupled with what appear to be more frequent outbreaks in the country, raises questions about the allocation of U.S. global health resources and bilateral aid for DRC.
authors: Salaam-Blyther, Tiaji ; Arieff, Alexis

title: Coping with the Mental Health Effects of COVID-19
annotation: The National Institutes of Health (NIH) is striving to combat the COVID-19 pandemic through a multifaceted approach that includes ensuring that the resources and support needed to manage stress and promote mental health are available. To support this effort, NIH presented this one-hour lecture on coping with the mental health effects of the COVID-19 pandemic.
authors: Everly, George; Collins, Francis

title: Protect a Generation: The Impact of COVID-19 on Children's Lives
annotation: This 46-page report summarizes a survey taken among children and their caregivers during the outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic, which found that 90 percent of the households that lost over half of their income due to the pandemic have struggled to access healthcare and medicine.
authors: Edwards, Jess
access_notes: Direct link to document: https://resourcecentre.savethechildren.net/node/18218/pdf/vr59-01_protect_a_generation_report_en_0.pdfLink to document in Arabic: https://resourcecentre.savethechildren.net/node/18218/pdf/protect_a_generation_executivesummary_arabic.pdfLink to document in French: https://resourcecentre.savethechildren.net/node/18218/pdf/protect_a_generation_executivesummary_french.pdfLink to document in Spanish: https://resourcecentre.savethechildren.net/node/18218/pdf/protect_a_generation_executivesummary_sp.pdf

title: Hidden Impact of COVID-19 on Children: A Global Research Series
annotation: This global study, with several documents, reveals the hidden impacts of COVID-19 pandemic response measures that are impacting children’s health, nutrition, education, learning, protection, well-being, family finances, and poverty.Population:  Adults and teens (NOTE: it’s ages 11 and up, actually)Length:  approximately 100 questionsTime to Complete:  25 minutesMode of Administration: Online (e.g., computer-assisted interview)Administered by:  Parent/Teacher; Self AdministeredLanguage(s): English; Albanian; Amharic; Arabic; Bangla; Burmese; Dari; Filipino/Tagalog; French/ Hindi; Iindonesian; Korean; Khmer; Lao; Mongolian; Mindanao; Nepali; Pashto; Portuguese; Serbian; Sinhala; Spanish; Tamil; Thai; Urdu; Vietnamese
access_notes: Free/Publicly Available Contact: Please contact the research team (attn: Melissa Burgess or Silvia Mila Arlini) at evidence.aro@savethechildren.org with any questions

title: COVID-19 Pandemic Planning Scenarios
source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Office of Infectious Diseases
annotation: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and the Office of the Assistant Secretary for Preparedness and Response have developed these five COVID-19 Pandemic Planning Scenarios, updated on September 10, 2020, that are designed to help inform decisions by modelers and public health officials who utilize mathematical modeling. The planning scenarios are being used by mathematical modelers throughout the federal government.

title: FAQs: Management of Infants Born to Mothers with Suspected or Confirmed COVID-19
annotation: These Frequently Asked Questions, updated on September 10, 2020, provide initial guidance for the management of infants born to mothers with confirmed and suspected COVID-19.

title: Waves, Forest Fires, and Herd Immunity: The Language of a Pandemic
source: Harvard University, Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health
annotation: This 36-minute presentation discusses the COVID-19 pandemic, the regrets that have characterized the pandemic to date, and the language of the pandemic that has shaped public understanding and action.
authors: Jones, David

title: Fair Allocation Mechanism for COVID-19 Vaccines Through the COVAX Facility
annotation: This 17-page document describes the WHO Secretariat’s proposal for the allocation of COVID-19 vaccines among countries (not within countries), specifically in the context of the COVID-19 Vaccines Global Access (COVAX) Facility access mechanism and developed in collaboration with the ACT-Accelerator vaccine partners.
access_notes: Direct link to document: https://www.who.int/docs/default-source/coronaviruse/who-covid19-vaccine-allocation-final-working-version-9sept.pdf?sfvrsn=e1d0376_2&download=true

title: Eldercare in the Time of COVID-19
annotation: This 53-minute webinar discusses topics that include caring for elders during the COVID-19 pandemic, preventing infection among this vulnerable population, tips for caregivers, and information about helping and protecting elders in the community.

title: ASPR TRACIE (Assistant Secretary for Preparedness and Response/Technical Resources, Assistance Center, and Information Exchange) Technical Assistance Request: Injury Types Due to Explosions
source: Office of the Assistant Secretary for Preparedness and Response [U.S. Department of Health and Human Services]
annotation: This five-page document from TRACIE (Technical Resources, Assistance Center, and Information Exchange) provides resources for a hospital that is working with its region’s healthcare coalition on a trauma mass casualty incident (MCI) virtual tabletop exercise (TTX), and would like to use the industry site explosion that occurred in Beirut, Lebanon, on August 4, 2020, as its TTX scenario. The requestor asked if ASPR TRACIE could help identify updated figures on the number of people injured and killed by the Beirut explosion, and the mechanism of injuries from the incident to help with victimology for the exercise’s scenario.

title: Fact Sheet for Healthcare Providers: Wantai SARS-CoV-2 RT-PCR Kit
annotation: This three-page fact sheet informs healthcare providers of the significant known and potential risks and benefits of the emergency use of the Wantai SARS-CoV-2 RT-PCR Kit. The Wantai SARS-CoV-2 RT-PCR Kit is authorized for use with oropharyngeal swab specimens collected from individuals suspected of COVID-19 by their healthcare provider.
access_notes: Link to Fact Sheet for Patients: https://www.fda.gov/media/141996/downloadLink to Letter of Authorization: https://www.fda.gov/media/141994/downloadLink to Instructions for Use: https://www.fda.gov/media/141997/download

title: Fact Sheet for Healthcare Providers: BioCheck SARS-CoV-2 IgG Antibody Test Kit
annotation: This three-page fact sheet informs healthcare providers of the significant known and potential risks and benefits of the emergency use of the BioCheck SARS-CoV-2 IgG    Antibody Test Kit. The BioCheck SARS-CoV-2 IgG Antibody Test Kit is authorized for the qualitative detection of IgG antibodies to SARS-CoV-2 in human serum.
access_notes: Link to Fact Sheet for Recipients: https://www.fda.gov/media/142005/downloadLink to Letter of Authorization: https://www.fda.gov/media/142003/downloadLink to Instructions for Use: https://www.fda.gov/media/142006/download

title: Fact Sheet for Healthcare Providers: BioCheck SARS-CoV-2 IgM Antibody Test Kit
annotation: This three-page fact sheet informs healthcare providers of the significant known and potential risks and benefits of the emergency use of the BioCheck SARS-CoV-2 IgM Antibody Test Kit. The BioCheck SARS-CoV-2 IgM Antibody Test Kit is authorized for the qualitative detection of IgM antibodies to SARS-CoV-2 in human serum.
access_notes: Link to Fact Sheet for Recipients: https://www.fda.gov/media/142000/downloadLink to Letter of Authorization: https://www.fda.gov/media/141998/downloadLink to Instructions for Use: https://www.fda.gov/media/142002/download

title: CC (Clinical Center) Grand Rounds: Contemporary Clinical Medicine: Great Teachers: Treating the Other Epidemic: Anti-Opioid Vaccines
annotation: This one-hour presentation discusses the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on fentanyl overdoses and abuse in the U.S. opioid pandemic, the limitations for preventing fentanyl overdose for existing maintenance treatments, and lessons learned from 25 years of clinical trials of stimulant vaccine efficacy.
authors: Kosten, Thomas

title: Vaccines: Saving Lives, Ensuring Confidence, and Protecting Public Health
source: U.S. Senate, Committee on Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions
annotation: The two government witnesses in this two-hour, 55-minute Congressional hearing discuss ongoing clinical trials of COVID-19 vaccine candidates, and some of the challenges the government faces in distributing a vaccine, which include misinformation about vaccines, and the current drop in general vaccination rates due to misinformation and distrust of government.
authors: Collins, Francis; Adams, Jerome

title: Select Toxin Guidance: Regulatory Exemptions
source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Center for Preparedness and Response
annotation: This guidance from the Division of Select Agents and Toxins, updated in September 2020, provides a list of product exemptions and investigational product exemption requirements for select toxins.

title: Guidance for Select Agent Regulation Training Requirements: Training Program
source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Center for Preparedness and Response
annotation: This guidance from the Division of Select Agents and Toxins, updated in September 2020, provides guidance about the regulatory requirements for training that are found in Section 15 of the select agent regulations. Individuals that access select agents and toxins must know the requirements of their entity's safety, security, and incident response programs if their entity is to be compliant. The regulations define the training that must be provided, who must receive the training, and how often the training must be provided.

title: Infectious Diseases Society of America Guidance on the Treatment of Antimicrobial Resistant Gram-Negative Infections
annotation: The overarching goal of this guidance is to assist clinicians – including those with and without infectious diseases expertise – in selecting antibiotic therapy for infections caused by ESBL-E, CRE, and DTR-P. aeruginosa. The guidance is framed as answers to a series of clinical questions, each of which can stand on its own.
authors: Tamma, Pranita; Ailken, Samuel; Bonomo, Robert; Mathers, Amy; Van Duin, David

title: Promising Strategies for Encouraging the Adoption of COVID-19 Protective Behaviors
source: National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine
annotation: This one-hour webinar discusses promising strategies from the behavioral and social sciences to make the adoption of protective behaviors against COVID-19 more likely. New guidance from the Societal Experts Action Network (SEAN) helps decision-makers understand strategies to increase adherence to protective behaviors to mitigate the spread of COVID-19.
authors: Brossard, Dominique; Wood, Wendy; Carlee, Ron; Graves, Robert

title: Fact Sheet for Healthcare Providers: Verily COVID-19 RT-PCR Test
annotation: This three-page fact sheet informs healthcare providers of the significant known and potential risks and benefits of the emergency use of the Verily COVID-19 RT-PCR Test. The Verily COVID-19 RT-PCR Test is authorized for use with respiratory specimens collected from individuals suspected of COVID-19 by their healthcare provider.
access_notes: Link to Fact Sheet for Patients: https://www.fda.gov/media/141950/downloadLink to Letter of Authorization: https://www.fda.gov/media/141948/downloadLink to EUA Summary: https://www.fda.gov/media/141951/download

title: COVID-19: Mental Health and Wellbeing Surveillance Report
annotation: This report, available with links to individual chapters, is about population mental health and well-being in England during the COVID-19 pandemic. It includes up-to-date information to inform policy, planning, and commissioning in health and social care.

title: Weight Management Services During COVID-19: Phase 1 Insights
annotation: This 69-page document is a rapid review to gain an understanding of how the pandemic affected people in lockdown, changes to weight management delivery and commissioning, and how services need to adapt in response to the recovery strategy.
access_notes: Direct link to document: https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/915274/WMS_Report.pdf

title: COVID-19: Long-Term Health Effects
annotation: This document provides information on the health problems reported in COVID-19 cases following acute disease, and guidance for healthcare professionals on how to advise recovering COVID-19 patients.
access_notes: Direct link to report: https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/covid-19-long-term-health-effects/covid-19-long-term-health-effects

title: COVID-19: Guidance for Managing a Funeral During the Coronavirus Pandemic
annotation: This guidance provides advice to assist people who are involved in managing or organizing a funeral related to a death from any cause during the coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic.
access_notes: Guidance is available in Arabic, Bengali, Simplified Chinese, Traditional Chinese, French, Gujarati, Polish, Portuguese, Punjabi, and Urdu.

title: Fact Sheet for Healthcare Providers: qSanger-COVID-19 Assay
annotation: This three-page fact sheet informs healthcare providers of the significant known and potential risks and benefits of the emergency use of the qSanger-COVID-19 Assay. The qSanger-COVID-19 Assay is authorized for use with upper respiratory specimens collected from individuals suspected of COVID-19 by their healthcare provider.
access_notes: Link to Fact Sheet for Patients: https://www.fda.gov/media/141934/downloadLink to Letter of Authorization: https://www.fda.gov/media/141932/downloadLink to Instructions for Use: https://www.fda.gov/media/141935/download

title: Mutual Recognition Agreements in the Regulation of Medicines
source: National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine
annotation: This one-hour, 34-minute webinar focuses on the barriers to greater use of regulatory reliance during the COVID-19 pandemic by drawing upon messages from the recently released National Academies report on regulatory reliance.
authors: Wood, Alistair; Lumpkin, Murray; Rasi, Guido; Cooke, Emer; Bernat, Janis
access_notes: Link to related report: Regulating Medicines in a Globalized World: The Need for Increased Reliance Among Regulators: https://www.nap.edu/catalog/25594/regulating-medicines-in-a-globalized-world-the-need-for-increased

title: Interim Guidance for Rapid Antigen Testing for SARS-CoV-2
source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Office of Infectious Diseases
annotation: The purpose of this interim technical guidance, updated on September 4, 2020, is to support the most effective use of antigen tests for SARS-CoV-2 for different testing situations. It applies to all uses of antigen tests and is not specific to the application of antigen tests to any particular age group or setting. It is intended for clinicians who order antigen tests, receive antigen test results, and/or perform point-of-care testing, as well as for laboratory professionals who perform antigen testing in a laboratory setting or at the point of care and report those results.

title: Infection Prevention and Control for the Safe Management of a Dead Body in the Context of COVID-19
annotation: This seven-page interim guidance, updated on September 4, 2020, is for all those, including managers of health care facilities and mortuaries, religious and public health authorities, and families, who tend to the bodies of persons who have died of suspected or confirmed COVID-19.
access_notes: Direct link to document: https://apps.who.int/iris/rest/bitstreams/1300088/retrieve

title: Contact Tracing and Case Investigation Training Modules
source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Office of Infectious Diseases
annotation: The trainings listed on this web page are for public health professionals or the general public who are interested in becoming a contact tracer or case investigator, as well as for public health professionals who already serve in these roles and are seeking to improve their knowledge.

title: ASPR TRACIE (Assistant Secretary for Preparedness and Response/Technical Resources, Assistance Center, and Information Exchange) Technical Assistance Request: COVID-19 and Seasonal Flu Vaccination Planning Resources
source: Office of the Assistant Secretary for Preparedness and Response [U.S. Department of Health and Human Services]
annotation: This four-page document from TRACIE (Technical Resources, Assistance Center, and Information Exchange) responds to a request for information and resources on how healthcare facilities are planning for seasonal influenza vaccination, including the possibility of also providing COVID-19 vaccination during flu season.

title: Guidance for Licensed Pharmacists and Pharmacy Interns Regarding COVID-19 Vaccines and Immunity under the PREP Act
source: Office of the Assistant Secretary for Health [U.S. Department of Health and Human Services]
annotation: This three-page guidance authorizes state-licensed pharmacists to order and administer, and state-licensed or registered pharmacy interns acting under the supervision of the qualified pharmacist to administer, to persons ages three or older COVID-19 vaccinations that have been authorized or licensed by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA).

title: Calculating Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) Laboratory Test Percent Positivity
source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Office of Infectious Diseases
annotation: This web page about SARS-CoV-2 laboratory testing details Using Percent Positivity Calculation for Public Health Surveillance, Different Methods Used to Calculate Percent Positivity, CDC Methods for Calculating Percent Positivity, and Data resources where percent positivity for COVID-19 are currently reported.

title: Principles for Managing SARS-CoV-2 Transmission Associated with Higher Education
annotation: This 32-page paper is provided in the context of existing guidance and higher education sector plans, and aims to supplement these by summarizing the latest evidence relating to SARS-CoV-2 transmission associated with the resumption of higher education activities from Autumn 2020, particularly the return of undergraduate and postgraduate students.
access_notes: Direct link to document: https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/914978/S0728_Principles_for_Managing_SARS-CoV-2_Transmission_Associated_with_Higher_Education_.pdf

title: Medical Gloves for COVID-19
annotation: To help expand the availability of medical gloves, the FDA is providing regulatory flexibility, as described in the enforcement policy for gloves that is in effect during the COVID-19 public health emergency. The FDA is also providing regular updates about medical gloves, including the answers to frequently asked questions on this page.

title: Fact Sheet for Healthcare Providers: SGTi-flex COVID-19 IgG
annotation: This three-page fact sheet informs healthcare providers of the significant known and potential risks and benefits of the emergency use of the SGTi-flex COVID-19 IgG. The SGTi-flex COVID-19 IgG is authorized for the detection of IgG antibodies to SARS-CoV-2 in human serum, venous whole blood (sodium heparin, lithium heparin, sodium citrate and tripotassium EDTA), andplasma (sodium heparin, lithium heparin, sodium citrate and tripotassium EDTA).
access_notes: Link to Fact Sheet for Recipients: https://www.fda.gov/media/141890/downloadLink to Letter of Authorization: https://www.fda.gov/media/141888/downloadLink to Instructions for Use: https://www.fda.gov/media/141891/download

title: Fact Sheet for Healthcare Providers: cobas SARS-CoV-2 & Influenza A/B
annotation: This four-page fact sheet informs healthcare providers of the significant known and potential risks and benefits of the emergency use of the cobas SARS-CoV-2 & Influenza A/B assay. Testing is to be conducted on specimens from individuals suspected of respiratory viral infection consistent with COVID-19 by their healthcare provider.
access_notes: Link to Fact Sheet for Patients: https://www.fda.gov/media/141886/downloadLink to Letter of Authorization: https://www.fda.gov/media/141884/downloadLink to Instructions for Use: https://www.fda.gov/media/141887/download

title: Impact of the COVID-19 Pandemic on Noncommunicable Disease Resources and Services: Results of a Rapid Assessment
annotation: This 32-page report presents the results of a rapid assessment conducted by the Noncommunicable Disease Department in May 2020 detailing the initial impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on noncommunicable disease resources and services.
access_notes: Direct link to document: https://apps.who.int/iris/rest/bitstreams/1299882/retrieve

title: Enforcement of Physical Health Protections for Front-line Workers
source: National Association of County and City Health Officials
annotation: This one-hour, 30-minute webinar explores how we ensure that all workers have access to the protective gear and procedures they need to remain safe and healthy during the COVID-19 pandemic, especially ones working in heavily impacted industries. Presenters discuss equitable enforcement of public health orders, workers’ rights, and employer responsibilities during this time.
authors: Carlisle, L.D.; Hani, Krista; Jones, Melissa

title: Coronavirus (COVID-19): Admission and Care of People in Care Homes
annotation: This guidance for how to protect care home residents and staff during the coronavirus outbreak is for care homes, local health protection teams, local authorities, clinical commissioning groups (CCGs), and registered providers of accommodation for people who need personal or nursing care.
access_notes: Guidance is available on a web page and in a PDF file.

title: Fact Sheet for Healthcare Providers: Bio-Speedy Direct RT-qPCR SARS-CoV-2
annotation: This three-page fact sheet informs healthcare providers of the significant known and potential risks and benefits of the emergency use of the Bio-Speedy Direct RT-qPCR SARS-CoV-2. The Bio-Speedy Direct RT-qPCR SARS-CoV-2 is authorized for use with respiratory specimens collected from individuals suspected of COVID-19 by their healthcare provider.
access_notes: Link to Fact Sheet for Patients: https://www.fda.gov/media/141825/downloadLink to Letter of Authorization: https://www.fda.gov/media/141824/downloadLink to Instructions for Use: https://www.fda.gov/media/141823/download

title: Interim SARS-CoV-2 Testing Guidelines for Patients in Outpatient Hemodialysis Facilities
source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Office of Infectious Diseases
annotation: While this guidance focuses on testing patients undergoing hemodialysis at outpatient hemodialysis facilities, several of the recommendations – such as testing patients with signs or symptoms of COVID-19 and testing asymptomatic close contacts – should also be applied to end-stage renal disease patients undergoing home dialysis (i.e., home hemodialysis or peritoneal dialysis).

title: Emergency Department Testing for COVID-19
source: National Emerging Special Pathogens Training and Education Center
annotation: COVID-19 testing strategies impact overall hospital operations, including the need for cohorting any amount of personal protective equipment used. Review the guidelines on this page to help balance the safety and efficacy of testing at your facility.

title: Corticosteroids for COVID-19
annotation: Corticosteroids have received worldwide attention as a potentially effective treatment for COVID-19. This 25-page guideline reflects an innovation from the World Health Organization, driven by an urgent need for global collaboration to provide trustworthy and living COVID-19 guidance informing policy and practice worldwide during an outbreak of an emerging infectious disease, such as this pandemic.
access_notes: Direct link to document: https://apps.who.int/iris/rest/bitstreams/1299344/retrieve

title: Recommendations for Investigational COVID-19 Convalescent Plasma
annotation: This guidance, updated on September 2, has been issued to provide recommendations to health care providers and investigators on the administration and study of investigational convalescent plasma collected from individuals who have recovered from COVID-19 (COVID-19 convalescent plasma) during the public health emergency.

title: Investigational COVID-19 Convalescent Plasma: Guidance for Industry
annotation: This 17-page guidance, updated on September 2, 2020, provides recommendations to healthcare providers and investigators on the administration and study of investigational convalescent plasma collected from individuals who have recovered from COVID-19 (COVID-19 convalescent plasma) during the public health emergency. The guidance also provides recommendations to blood establishments on the collection of COVID-19 convalescent plasma.
access_notes: Direct link to document: https://www.fda.gov/media/136798/downloadThis document supersedes the guidance of the same title issued in April 2020 and updated in May 2020.

title: Security Challenge: Mob Attacks
annotation: Health facilities may be easy targets that are difficult to protect even with security measures in place. This four-page document describes a few measures that can be considered to pre-empt and prepare for mob attacks. The recommendations were developed  in collaboration with Christian Blind Mission (CBM) with advisory provided by RiskVisibility. They have been funded by the H2H Fund, which is supported by UK aid from the UK government.

title: Knowledge, Attitudes and Practices (KAP) Assessment on COVID-19
source: International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies
annotation: To understand communities’ knowledge, attitudes, and practices (KAP), along with their information needs on COVID-19, this 48-page KAP assessment was conducted by the Turkish Red Crescent Society (TRCS), with support from IFRC, under the Community Based Migration Programme (CBMP). The findings are intended to inform understanding of community perceptions of, and knowledge about, COVID-19 and, in turn, shape risk communication, behavior change, and community engagement activities.
access_notes: Direct link to document: https://data2.unhcr.org/en/documents/download/82472

title: Influenza and Other Respiratory Viruses: Surveillance in the Americas 2019
source: World Health Organization, Pan American Health Organization
annotation: This 136-page third edition of the landscape analysis of Influenza and Other Respiratory Viruses: Surveillance in the Americas provides regional and country-specific data of regional trends that include surveillance of severe acute respiratory infection (SARI), influenza-like illness (ILI), influenza vaccine, FluNet/FluID reporting, and participation in WHO’s External Quality Assessment Project (EQAP).
access_notes: Direct link to document: https://iris.paho.org/bitstream/handle/10665.2/52741/9789275122792lowres_eng.pdf?sequence=1&isAllowed=y

title: Impact of Coronavirus on Households Across America
annotation: This series of five polls conducted by NPR, the Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health, and the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation, finds that a substantial share of U.S. households have not been protected from serious impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic across many areas of residents' lives.

title: Washing/Drying of Biological Agent Contaminated Clothing
annotation: The overall purpose of this 91-page study was to assess the use of washers and dryers with a suitable decontamination solution as a potential self-help practice to reduce and/or inactivate biological spores from common clothing material. This approach may be used to lessen potential cross-contamination among emergency first responders, security personnel, or members of the public exposed to a wide area B. anthracis spore release.
authors: Touati, Abderrahmane; Serre, Shannon
access_notes: Direct link to document: https://cfpub.epa.gov/si/si_public_file_download.cfm?p_download_id=541299&Lab=CESER

title: AMR (Antimicrobial Resistance) in the Light of COVID-19 Webinar Series
annotation: The Antimicrobial Resistance Fighter Coalition, in partnership with CIDRAP, the American Society for Microbiology, Wellcome, the Surveillance and Epidemiology of Drug-resistant Infections Consortium, and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, is hosting this webinar series about how the COVID-19 pandemic could reshape strategies for combating antimicrobial resistance around the world.

title: COVID-19 and Achieving Health Equity
source: U.S. Senate, Committee on Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions
annotation: This 46-page report examines the intersection of the COVID-19 pandemic, inequality in infection rates and health outcomes, and structural racism within the health care system. It describes the impact of COVID-19 on the health of communities of color and discusses a few of the factors that have contributed to inequality in health outcomes,  including  exploitation of communities of color, segregation, discrimination, and bias within the health care system, lack of access to high-quality care, and social  determinants of health.

title: COVID-19 Operationalization of the Global Response Strategy in the WHO European Region
source: World Health Organization, Regional Office for Europe
annotation: This 35-page document outlines the WHO European Regional strategy to respond to COVID-19 and its consequences, based on WHO’s global strategy update for COVID-19, covering the period February-December 2020. The strategy is flexible and adaptable to national and subnational contexts, and guides countries in rapidly bringing COVID-19 cases under control, and in preparing for a phased transition from a widespread transmission to a steady state of low-level or no transmission.
access_notes: Direct link to document: https://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/handle/10665/334167/WHO-EURO-2020-1073-408190-55167-eng.pdfLink to document in Russian: https://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/handle/10665/335913/WHO-EURO-2020-1073-40819-55171-rus.pdf?sequence=1&isAllowed=y

title: Opportunities for U.S. Civilian and Military Collaboration in Health Surveillance and Emergency Preparedness
source: Johns Hopkins Center for Public Health Preparedness [Johns Hopkins University]
annotation: This conference features presentations from 11 speakers discussing civilian and military collaboration in emergency preparedness. Topics covered include an overview of the military surveillance systems, the role of the military in emergency response, an overview of civilian surveillance and response systems, military public health emergency management and support to civil authorities, and legal challenges. Several case studies are presented and discusses.
authors: Barnett, Daniel J.; Otto, Jean; DeFraites, Robert
access_notes: Site requires free registration.

title: Guide to Public Health Measures to Reduce the Impact of Influenza Pandemics in Europe
source: European Union, European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control
annotation: This 51-page document contains a selection of possible public measures to be taken during influenza pandemics, including personal protective measures, social distancing measures, antivirals, and vaccines.
access_notes: Direct link to document: https://www.ecdc.europa.eu/sites/default/files/media/en/publications/Publications/0906_TER_Public_Health_Measures_for_Influenza_Pandemics.pdf

title: Model Memorandum of Understanding Between Hospitals during Declared Emergencies
source: National Center for the Study of Preparedness and Catastrophic Event Response [Johns Hopkins University]
annotation: This is a memorandum of understanding  designed to assist with potential collaborative efforts among hospitals and potentially other healthcare facilities.

title: WHO Regional Office for Europe Recommendations on Influenza Vaccination for the 2020/2021 Season During the Ongoing  COVID-19 Pandemic
source: World Health Organization, Regional Office for Europe
annotation: This seven-page document details how it will be critical in the upcoming influenza season to implement comprehensive measures that ensure best possible protection against influenza among risk groups that are also at high risk of severe COVID-19 disease, including hospitalization and death; decrease number of persons requiring medical care as a result of influenza infection to limit pressures on health services; and reduce the potential for SARS-CoV-2 exposure while seeking treatment for influenza or being admitted to hospital for influenza.
access_notes: Direct link to document: https://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/handle/10665/335721/WHO-EURO-2020-1141-40887-55342-eng.pdf?sequence=1&isAllowed=yLink to document in Russian: https://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/handle/10665/335722/WHO-EURO-2020-1141-40887-55343-rus.pdf?sequence=1&isAllowed=y

title: Flatten Inaccessibility: Impact of COVID-19 on Blind or Visually Impaired Adults
annotation: This 94-page report provides information and results from a survey that investigated the experiences of participants who are blind or have low vision during the start of the COVID-19 pandemic to determine how they were affected in areas that include access to transportation, healthcare, access to food and supplies, employment, education, and voting.
authors: Rosenblum, L. Penny; Chanes-Mora, Paola; McBride, C. Rett; Flewellen, Joshua; Nagarajan, Niranjani

title: 2020 Public Health Law Virtual Summit: COVID-19 Response and Recovery
annotation: This two-day summit, held on September 16-17, 2020, featured experts who presented their key findings from the report on Assessing Legal Responses to COVID-19, and proposed paths forward to more effective and equitable response and recovery efforts. This web page provides links to recordings of all sessions.
authors: Silverman, Ross; Oliva, Jennifer; Wiley, Lindsay; Haddow, Kim; Burris, Scott
access_notes: Link to Disaster Lit record for Assessing Legal Responses to COVID-19: https://disasterinfo.nlm.nih.gov/search/id:23452.

title: Advancing CHW (Community Health Worker) Engagement in COVID-19 Response Strategies
source: National Association of Community Health Workers
annotation: This 19-page document provides practical guidance to conceptualize and operationalize community health worker (CHW) and CHW Network engagement in COVID-19 response. A matrix of areas of engagement and a continuum of engagement (low/harmful to robust) are offered for local, state, and national actors to consider who want to amplify the roles and capacity of the CHW workforce. It was developed in partnership with the Community Based Workforce Alliance.

title: 2009 Influenza A(H1N1) Outbreak
annotation: This 36-page document discusses legal issues related to emergency measures, civil rights, liability, and employment issues surrounding the health threat of a pandemic, including  emergency measures which may help to contain or ameliorate an infectious disease outbreak.
authors: Jones, Nancy Lee; Swendiman, Kathleen

title: Coronavirus Misinformation: Quantifying Sources and Themes in the COVID-19 "Infodemic"
annotation: This eight-page report summarizes a study that identifies the most prominent misinformation topics that appeared in traditional and online media in the early phase of the COVID-19 pandemic, from January 1 to May 26, 2020. The results come from a sample of 38 million articles published in English-language media around the world.
authors: Evanega, Sarah; Lynas, Mark; Adams, Jordan; Smolenyak, Karinne

title: Engaging with Local Faith Actors and Communities: A Toolkit
annotation: This 18-page toolkit aims to help answer the question of what staff in European Union Delegations or the ECHO field office can do to engage with religious leaders and faith communities when faced with a crisis with urgency of a pandemic such as COVID-19 or Ebola.

title: Protecting Children: Coronavirus Considerations with Dr. Brent Kaziny
annotation: This course discusses how coronavirus impacts children, answers to frequently asked questions, health screenings, how the fall/winter flu season may impact coronavirus, and how we should handle children that present at health screenings with fever/signs of illness.
authors: Roszak, Andrew; Kaziny, Brent
access_notes: Site requires free registration.

title: Protecting Children: Learning From Las Vegas Mass Shooting Survivor Lacey Newman
annotation: Participants in this course will learn to describe at least two steps they can take to be better prepared, identify at least two considerations when discussing these events to children, and describe two techniques to help stay calm during an emergency.
authors: Roszak, Andrew; Newman, Lacey
access_notes: Site requires free registration.

title: CONVERGE Conducting Emotionally Challenging Research Training Module
source: Natural Hazards Center [University of Colorado at Boulder]
annotation: This four-lesson training module describes emotionally challenging research and highlights the ways that recognizing researchers’ emotions can lead to more ethical and methodologically sound research practices in the context of extreme events.
access_notes: Site requires free registration.

title: Health Worker Safety and Security in the Context of the COVID-19 Pandemic
annotation: This four-page brief provides an overview of the most recent conflict-violence trends and their impact on health care in 2020, including data compiled during the COVID-19 pandemic.

title: Hidden Consequences: How the COVID Pandemic is Impacting Children
source: Office of the Assistant Secretary for Preparedness and Response [U.S. Department of Health and Human Services]
annotation: This one-page document provides information and links to recordings for a TRACIE (Technical Resources, Assistance Center, and Information Exchange) webinar series focused on how the COVID-19 pandemic may affect children. Topics will include impacts on child health and wellness, child emotional and social effects, the impact of COVID-19 on children with special healthcare needs, and how secondary/other disasters may affect children during the pandemic.

title: Long-Term Care Facilities in the Context of COVID-19
annotation: This course consists of four modules that address infection prevention and control measures to support long-term care facilities in the context of COVID-19. Participants will learn to describe infection prevention and control principles and practices relevant to long-term care facilities for patient and staff safety during COVID-19, and apply the COVID-19 Long-Term Care Facility Checklist to their place of work.
access_notes: Site requires free registration.

title: Ebola: Introduction
annotation: This introductory session explains basic principles of Ebola disease and ways to protect yourself and others. By the end of this lecture, participants will be able to describe Ebola disease and how it is transmitted, recall basic measures to prevent Ebola disease, and list key public health concerns during an Ebola outbreak.
access_notes: Site requires free registration.Link to course in French: https://openwho.org/courses/introduction-a-ebolaLink to course in Lingala: https://openwho.org/courses/ebola-introduction-LNLink to course in Kiswahili: https://openwho.org/courses/ebola-introduction-SW

title: COVID-19: Community Insights from the Asia Pacific Region
source: International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies
annotation: This 16-page report summarizes the results of a survey initiated by the Asia Pacific Risk Communication and Community Engagement Working Group to find out what people know about the COVID-19 virus and how it spreads, in order to enable stronger community-based response. Reporting data was collected from May 29 to July 20, 2020, by the Red Cross and Red Crescent Movement, WHO, OCHA, UNICEF, and Kantar.
authors: Adsett, Eloise; Arriani, Aulia; Austin, Caroline; Bartholomew, Katie; Fluck, Viviane

title: Health and Social Services in Puerto Rico Before and After Hurricane Maria
annotation: In September 2017, Puerto Rico was struck by Hurricanes Irma and Maria. To establish an evidence-based foundation for the recovery plan, the Homeland Security Operational Analysis Center (HSOAC) was asked to conduct an assessment describing the damage from the hurricanes and remaining needs across Puerto Rico. This 215-page report focuses on the damage and needs assessment and related courses of action, which are a collection of activities, policies, and actions that support the human capital investments and that were developed for Puerto Rico’s health and social services sector by the Health and Social Services Sector team.
authors: Chandra, Anita; Marsh, Terry; Madrigano, Jaime; Simmons, Molly; Abir, Mahshid
access_notes: Direct link to document: https://www.rand.org/content/dam/rand/pubs/research_reports/RR2600/RR2603/RAND_RR2603.pdfLink to research summary: https://www.rand.org/content/dam/rand/pubs/research_reports/RR2600/RR2603/RAND_RR2603.summary.pdf

title: Is the Rise in Illicit Opioids Affecting Labor Supply and Disability Claiming Rates?
annotation: This 63-page paper examines how the recent transition of the opioid crisis from prescription opioids to more prevalent misuse of illicit opioids, such as heroin and fentanyl, altered labor supply behavior and disability insurance claiming rates. It exploits differential geographic exposure to the reformulation of OxyContin, the largest reduction in access to abusable prescription opioids to date, to study the effects of substitution to illicit markets.
authors: Park, Sujeong; Powell, David
access_notes: Direct link to document: https://www.rand.org/content/dam/rand/pubs/working_papers/WRA800/WRA802-1/RAND_WRA802-1.pdf

title: CRED Crunch 60: Technological Disasters
source: Centre for Research on the Epidemiology of Disasters, a WHO Collaborating Centre
annotation: This two-page report analyzes data about technological disasters from 1980 to 2019, including the types of disasters and geographical locations.
authors: van Loenhout, Joris; Below, Regina; Horions, Matthias

title: COVID-19: Considerations, Strategies, and Resources for Crisis Standards of Care in Post-Acute and Long-Term Care (PALTC) Facilities
source: U.S. Department of Health and Human Services
annotation: This 36-page document from the COVID-19 Healthcare Resilience Working Group provides post-acute and long-term care facilities an overview of general considerations, potential strategies, and existing resources that they may use to inform changes to their operations and care processes during the COVID-19 pandemic. Sample tools and resources are provided for illustrative purposes only and should be modified to locally adopted protocols as appropriate.

title: COVID-19 and Violence Against Women and Children: A Second Research Round Up
annotation: This 11-page report summarizes a study that reviewed 28 new reports about violence against women during the COVID-19 pandemic, and found increasing evidence that the COVID-19 pandemic and associated policy response measures increase violence against women and children across contexts.
authors: Peterman, Amber; O'Donnell, Megan
access_notes: Direct link to document: https://www.cgdev.org/sites/default/files/covid-19-and-violence-against-women-and-children-second-research-round.pdf

title: COVID-19 FAQs: What Nurses Need to Know
annotation: This web page provides answers to some of the most common questions that the American Nurses Association has received about COVID-19, including clinical care, personal protective equipment (PPE), mental health, and licensure.

title: In Pursuit of Resilience: Assessing Threats and Trade-Offs for Risk-Informed Development in Myanmar and Niger
annotation: This 61-page report builds on its predecessor – Risk-Informed Development: From Crisis to Resilience –  to inform the potential evolution of proposed or existing policies through case study applications of a risk-informed development (RID) approach. The approach was used for systematically assessing multiple, simultaneous threats and their interactions with policies, as well as potential trade-offs from policies, in two contexts: Myanmar and Niger.
authors: Mayhew, Leigh; Pichon, Florence; Opitz-Stapleton, Sarah; Nadin, Rebecca
access_notes: Direct link to document: https://www.odi.org/sites/odi.org.uk/files/resource-documents/202009_in_pursuit_of_resilience_rid_report.pdfLink to Disaster Lit record for Risk-Informed Development: From Crisis to Resilience: https://disasterinfo.nlm.nih.gov/search/id:19413

title: GLASS (Global Antimicrobial Resistance and Use Surveillance System) Guidance for National Reference Laboratories
annotation: Countries can use this 28-page technical guidance to establish or improve national reference laboratory capacity within the national antimicrobial resistance (AMR) surveillance system. Increased laboratory capacity in countries and rapid, accurate diagnostic testing will significantly strengthen global AMR surveillance and diagnostic stewardship.
access_notes: Direct link to document: https://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/handle/10665/334290/9789240010581-eng.pdf?sequence=1&isAllowed=y

title: Framework for Evaluating Approaches to Symptom Screening in the Workplace During the COVID-19 Pandemic
annotation: The authors of this 20-page report assess five approaches to screening for symptoms of COVID-19 at the workplace: no screening, verbal screening, screening using a paper form or app, verbal screening plus a temperature check at the workplace, and screening using a paper form or app plus a temperature check at the workplace. They rate each approach on five criteria: likelihood of detecting infection, helping employees feel safer, safety of the screening interaction, feasibility, and privacy.
authors: Gidengil, Courtney; Fischer, Shira; Breton, Nicholas
access_notes: Direct link to document: https://www.rand.org/content/dam/rand/pubs/perspectives/PEA600/PEA653-1/RAND_PEA653-1.pdf

title: COVID-19 Air Traffic Visualization: African Anchor States Face Higher Risk of Importing COVID-19 Cases
annotation: This report uses the COVID-19 Air Traffic Visualization (CAT-V) tool to quantify the potential vectors of COVID-19 transmission to countries in the U.S. Africa Command (AFRICOM) area of responsibility (AOR), which encompasses every country in Africa except Egypt.
authors: Hanson, Russell; Grissom, Adam; Mouton, Christopher; Godges, John

title: COVID-19 Air Traffic Visualization: Worldwide Spread of COVID-19 Accelerated Starting on February 19, 2020
annotation: This report uses the COVID-19 Air Traffic Visualization (CAT-V) tool to estimate when COVID-19 transmission via commercial air travel began to rapidly accelerate throughout the world. It estimates the global spread of COVID-19 by international air passengers prior to the March 11, 2020, declaration by the World Health Organization (WHO) that the world was officially experiencing a pandemic.
authors: Mouton, Christopher; Grissom, Adam; Godges, John; Hanson, Russell

title: COVID-19 Vaccinations: Liability and Compensation Considerations Critical for a Successful Campaign
annotation: The authors of this 16-page report examine liability and compensation issues as they relate to the future distribution and administration of the COVID-19 vaccine. They provide a brief history of how the U.S. government has addressed liability and compensation concerns in previous public health threats — specifically by providing liability immunity to manufacturers and distributors of vaccines should lawsuits arise as the result of serious side effects, as well as by setting up compensation systems that provide some, but not all, benefits of traditional tort litigation.
authors: Pace, Nicholas; Dixon, Lloyd
access_notes: Direct link to document: https://www.rand.org/content/dam/rand/pubs/perspectives/PEA700/PEA761-1/RAND_PEA761-1.pdf

title: Rapid Expert Consultation on Environmental Surveillance of SARS-CoV-2 in Wastewater
source: World Health Organization, Regional Office for Europe
annotation: This 19-page report summarizes the findings of the rapid expert consultation on environmental surveillance of SARS-CoV-2 in wastewater that was organized by the WHO European Centre for Environment and Health on July 23, 2020, in a virtual format. It aimed to facilitate a rapid exchange of current knowledge, experience, and practices among countries that are in the forefront of research and environmental surveillance of SARS-CoV-2 in wastewater.
access_notes: Direct link to document: https://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/handle/10665/334305/WHO-EURO-2020%20-1093-40839-55199-eng.pdf?sequence=3&isAllowed=y

title: COVID-19 Pandemic Response in the Eastern Mediterranean Region
source: World Health Organization, Regional Office for the Eastern Mediterranean
annotation: This 68-page report summarizes a six-month review of the Incident Management Support Team (IMST) response to the COVID-19 pandemic in the Eastern Mediterranean Region. A theme running throughout is the IMST’s role in coordination of the COVID-19 response, particularly in bringing together regional partners and driving forward the operational response.
access_notes: Direct link to document: https://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/handle/10665/334319/WHOEMHSEL002E-eng.pdf?sequence=1&isAllowed=y

title: Adapting Data Collection and Utilisation to a COVID-19 Reality
annotation: This 11-page briefing note focuses on the remote collection and use of data for adaptive management during the COVID-19 pandemic, setting out key considerations to help practitioners think through a transition from more traditional monitoring, evaluation, and learning (MEL) to MEL for adaptive management (MEL4AM) that reflects the unique data collection challenges presented by COVID-19.
authors: Ziegler, Jessica; Mason, Paige
access_notes: Direct link to document: https://www.odi.org/sites/odi.org.uk/files/resource-documents/odi-ml-mel4am-adaptingdatacollection-bn-sep20-final_3.pdf

title: Coronavirus Commission on Safety and Quality in Nursing Homes: Commission Final Report
annotation: This 186-page report summarizes an independent review and comprehensive assessment of the nursing home response to the COVID-19 pandemic in order to identify opportunities for improvement and inform immediate and future action. The Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) requested this commission of experts to solicit lessons learned from the early days of the pandemic and recommendations for future actions to improve infection prevention and control measures, safety procedures, and the quality of life of residents within nursing homes.

title: Technical Note: Impact of COVID-19 on Child Poverty
annotation: Using data on access to education, healthcare, housing, nutrition, sanitation, and water from more than 70 countries, this three-page document finds that around 45 percent of children were severely deprived of at least one of these critical needs before the coronavirus pandemic even hit. The situation for children living in multidimensional poverty is likely to worsen unless national governments and the international community step up to soften the blow.
access_notes: Direct link to document: https://data.unicef.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/Technical-Note-Save-the-Children-UNICEF-COVID-and-impact-on-multidimensional-child-poverty.pdf

title: Respiratory Health Effects of Airborne Hazards Exposures in the Southwest Asia Theater of Military Operations
annotation: This 254-page report reviews the scientific evidence regarding respiratory health outcomes in veterans of the Southwest Asia conflicts, and identifies research that could feasibly be conducted to address outstanding questions and generate answers, newly emerging technologies that could aid in these efforts, and organizations that the Veterans Administration might partner with to accomplish this work.

title: How COVID-19 is Changing the World: A Statistical Perspective
annotation: The United Nations and all member organizations of the Committee for the Coordination of Statistical Activities (CCSA) collect and make available a wealth of information for assessing the multifaceted impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic. This 80-page report updates some of the global and regional trends presented in Volume I and offers a snapshot of how COVID-19 continues to affect the world today across multiple domains.
access_notes: Direct link to document: file:///C:/Users/SINCLA~1/AppData/Local/Temp/COVID19-CCSA-report-final-English-Vol2_2020.pdf

title: Landscape of Emerging Infectious Disease R&D: Preventing the Next Pandemic
annotation: This 79-page report provides a comprehensive look at R&D to fight emerging infectious diseases (EIDs), covering global funding for WHO priority EIDs between 2014 and 2018. The funding data included in the report covers a range of pathogens with recognized pandemic potential, including coronaviruses, Ebola, Zika, and as-yet-unknown pathogens captured under the heading of Disease X.
authors: Chapman, Nick; Doubell, Anna; Tuttle, Andrew; Barnsley, Paul; Oversteegan, Lisette
access_notes: Link to Executive Summary: https://s3-ap-southeast-2.amazonaws.com/policy-cures-website-assets/app/uploads/2020/09/16021630/GFINDER_LEIDR_EXEC_SUMMARY.pdfLink to Explore data from the report: https://gfinderdata.policycuresresearch.org/

title: Expanding Our Vision for Mental Health: Listening to Young People and Learning from COVID-19
annotation: This seven-page document discusses how COVID-19 is an opportunity to learn about  mental health. It lays out a commitment by Wellcome, UNICEF, WHO, the World Economic  Forum, and the Office of the UN Secretary General to embark on a learning journey on how best to embed the following three principles across all our mental health work: Putting lived experience at the heart of policy and practice; positioning local innovation as a focus for learning and funding; and envisioning mental health as larger than healthcare.
authors: Smith, Beck; Wolpert, Miranda
access_notes: Direct link to document: https://wellcome.org/sites/default/files/expanding-our-vision-for-mental-health-young-people-and-covid-19.pdf

title: COVID-19 Mental Health Handbook: Evidence-Informed Approaches to Mental Wellbeing During a Pandemic
annotation: This 195-page handbook covers a range of topics that live at the intersection of COVID-19 and mental health. This resource brings to attention the myriad mental health needs COVID-19 has brought to the surface while also suggesting ways to cope, move forward, and become more resilient.
access_notes: Site requires free registration.

title: Maintaining Healthcare Safety During the COVID-19 Pandemic
source: Office of the Assistant Secretary for Preparedness and Response [U.S. Department of Health and Human Services]
annotation: This one-page document from TRACIE (Technical Resources, Assistance Center, and Information Exchange) provides links to a series of short presentations featuring healthcare professionals sharing their experiences as they work through the operational realities of maintaining and prioritizing healthcare safety during the COVID-19 pandemic.

title: Resuming Normal Drug and Biologics Manufacturing Operations During the COVID-19 Public Health Emergency
annotation: The FDA is issuing this 12-page guidance to help drug and biological product manufacturers during the COVID-19 public health emergency plan and prioritize current good manufacturing practice (CGMP) activities as they transition from operations impacted by the public health emergency to normal manufacturing operations.

title: Assessing COVID-19-Related Symptoms in Outpatient Adult and Adolescent Subjects in Clinical Trials of Drugs and Biological Products for COVID-19 Prevention or Treatment
annotation: The FDA is issuing this 14-page guidance to provide sponsors and investigators with considerations for approaches on how common COVID-19-related symptoms can be measured and analyzed in clinical trials evaluating drugs or biological products for the prevention or treatment of COVID-19 in outpatient adult and adolescent subjects.
access_notes: Direct link to document: https://www.fda.gov/media/142143/download

title: Moving Beyond the Numbers: What the COVID-19 Pandemic Means for the Safety of Women and Girls
annotation: This 10-page report illustrates some of the limitations of the statistics on gender-based violence that have been widely publicized in the context of the COVID-19 pandemic, provides additional contextual information to better understand the risks women and girls are facing, and outlines some priority recommendations to governments, policy makers, donors, and key humanitarian and development actors for addressing gender-based violence in the context of COVID-19.
access_notes: Direct link to document: https://aa9276f9-f487-45a2-a3e7-8f4a61a0745d.usrfiles.com/ugd/aa9276_0b3161f4941049e4a740ef8586c96c15.pdf

title: SocialNet2019 Community Engagement Training: White Paper and SocialNet Experience
source: World Health Organization, Regional Office for Europe
annotation: Over 50 participants from countries and territories in the WHO European Region participated in a training course on risk communication, community engagement, and social science. This 132-page training report consists of two main sections that both cover the core content, themes, and concepts of SocialNet – but considered through distinctive lenses.
access_notes: Direct link to document: https://www.euro.who.int/__data/assets/pdf_file/0004/461794/SocialNet2019.pdf

title: World in Disorder: 2020 Background Papers
annotation: As part of the process for developing its annual report, the Global Preparedness Monitoring Board commissions review papers from world experts and leading institutions that explore the challenges of preparedness through various lenses. This web page provides links to the 2020 background papers.
access_notes: Link to Governance Preparedness: Initial Lessons from COVID-19: https://apps.who.int/gpmb/assets/thematic_papers_2020/tp_2020_1.pdfLink to The Global Governance of Access to Countermeasures: https://apps.who.int/gpmb/assets/thematic_papers_2020/tp_2020_2.pdfLink to Building Trust Within and Across Communities for Health Emergency Preparedness: https://apps.who.int/gpmb/assets/thematic_papers_2020/tp_2020_3.pdfLink to Urbanization and Preparedness for Outbreaks with High-Impact Respiratory Pathogens: https://apps.who.int/gpmb/assets/thematic_papers_2020/tp_2020_4.pdfLink to The R&D Preparedness Ecosystem: Preparedness for Health Emergencies: https://apps.who.int/gpmb/assets/thematic_papers_2020/tp_2020_5.pdf

title: Region 1 Interagency Task Force for the Prevention of COVID-19 in the Long-Term Care Environment
source: Office of the Assistant Secretary for Preparedness and Response [U.S. Department of Health and Human Services]
annotation: This 20-page document, developed with the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA), provides the conclusions and recommendations of the task force formed by FEMA and ASPR to contribute specifically to combating the spread of COVID-19 and mitigating its impacts on residents of long-term care facilities.

title: Critical Care Load-Balancing Operational Template
source: Office of the Assistant Secretary for Preparedness and Response [U.S. Department of Health and Human Services]
annotation: This five-page template from the Healthcare Resilience Working Group provides a framework for indicators and triggers that may assist states that are implementing Medical Operations Coordination Cells (MOCCs). The goal of the MOCC toolkit is to assist regional, state, local, tribal, and territorial governments to ensure load-balancing across healthcare facilities and systems so that the highest possible level of care can be provided to each patient during the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) pandemic.

title: Considerations for Assessing Regional Patient Load-Balancing Effects during COVID-19
source: Office of the Assistant Secretary for Preparedness and Response [U.S. Department of Health and Human Services]
annotation: This four-page document from the Healthcare Resilience Working Group promotes constructs such as the Medical Operations Coordination Cell (MOCC) during the COVID-19 pandemic to create a regional approach, including policies to support these load-balancing operations, particularly through hospital-to-hospital patient transfers.

title: WHO Guidance on Research Methods for Health and Disaster Risk Management
annotation: This guidance offers practical advice about how to plan, conduct, and report on a wide variety of quantitative and qualitative studies that can inform questions about policies and programs for health-related disasters and emergencies across different settings and level of resources. Case studies of direct relevance to Health Emergency and Disaster Risk Management provide real-life examples of research methods and how they have modified policies.
authors: Abrahams, Jonathan; Kayano, Ryoma; Clarke, Mike; Chan, Emily YY; Murray, Virginia
access_notes: Chapter sections are available in individual PDF files.

title: COVID-19 Supplement for Planning Considerations: Evacuation and Shelter-in-Place
source: Federal Emergency Management Agency [Department of Homeland Security]
annotation: This 12-page document focuses on key considerations and principles associated with evacuation and shelter-in-place planning and execution, and identifies impacts that COVID-19 may have on planning and executing evacuation and shelter-in-place operations.

title: National Decision Point: Effective Testing and Screening for COVID-19
annotation: This 30-page report describes how to offer sufficient COVID-19 tests paired with sophisticated strategies for their effective use, in ways that can be tailored to local circumstances and risk tolerances. The goal is to give schools, businesses, and other critical institutions a pathway toward operating safely even for higher-risk populations and with continuing community spread.
authors: Silcox, Christina; Anderson, David; Zavodszky, Anna; Borre, Ethan; Dentzer, Susan
access_notes: Direct link to document: https://www.rockefellerfoundation.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/A-National-Decision-Point-Effective-Testing-Screening-for-Covid-19-Full-Report.pdfLink to Executive Summary: https://www.rockefellerfoundation.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/A-National-Decision-Point-Effective-Testing-Screening-for-Covid-19-Executive-Summary.pdf

title: COVID-19 Considerations for Long-Term Care Facilities
source: Office of the Assistant Secretary for Preparedness and Response [U.S. Department of Health and Human Services]
